revision.comment: concerns are noted, but the references say a) listeners are trained, and b) he's a psychologist
revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = 7 Cups (7 Cups of Tea) | logo = 7 Cups of Tea logo 2015.gif | logo_size = 140px | logo_alt = | logo_caption = <!-- or: | logocaption = --> | screenshot = | collapsible = <!-- set as "on", "y", etc, otherwise omit/leave blank --> | collapsetext = <!-- collapsible area's heading (default "Screenshot"); omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = <!-- default 300px --> | screenshot_alt = | caption = | url = {{URL|www.7cups.com}} | slogan = | commercial = Yes <!-- "Yes", "No" or leave blank --> | type = Emotional support website | registration = | language = Many languages | num_users = | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | programming_language = | owner = Glen Moriarty | author = <!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = <!-- or: | editors = --> | launch_date = July 2013 <!-- {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | revenue = | alexa = <!-- {{increase}} {{steady}} {{decrease}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/example.com ##] (US/Global MM/YYYY) --> | ip = | current_status = Online | footnotes = }}
'''7 Cups''' (formerly called '''7 Cups of Tea''') is a [[website]] (also available in an [[mobile application|app]]) which provides online therapy and free support to people experiencing [[Stress (medicine)|emotional distress]] by connecting them with trained listeners.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/08/05/y-combinator-startup-7-cups-of-tea-connects-people-in-need-of-emotional-support-with-trained-listeners/|title=Y Combinator Startup 7 Cups Of Tea Connects People In Need Of Emotional Support With Trained Listeners|last=Shu|first=Catherine|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2015/01/23/7-cups-of-tea-provides-247-emotional-support/|title=7 Cups of Tea provides 24/7 emotional support|date=2015-01-23|website=USA TODAY College|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref> The listener, trained in [[active listening]], interacts with the person seeking help via an anonymous and confidential chat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww2.kqed.org/futureofyou/2015/04/17/stressed-out-startup-founders-find-support-online/|title=Stressed-Out Startup Founders Find Support Online|website=KQED Future of You|language=en-us|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref> Members must be 13 to 17 on the teenage side and 18+ for the adult side. Listeners must be 15 or over.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iowastatedaily.com/news/student_life/article_21540770-b496-11e4-9dcd-df0295772d43.html|title=Free app provides emotional support for students|last=dakota.carpenter@iowastatedaily.com|first=Dakota Carpenter,|website=Iowa State Daily|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref>
The website derives its name from the [[eponym]]ous poem by the 9th century Chinese poet [[Lu Tong]]. It is a [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] [[startup company|startup]] founded by psychologist Glen Moriarty in July 2013.<ref name=":0" />
== References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.7cups.com/ 7 Cups of Tea site]

{{For|the Bill Bryson book and its film adaptation|A Walk in the Woods (disambiguation){{!}}A Walk in the Woods}} {{Infobox play |name=A Walk in the Woods |writer=[[Lee Blessing]] |premiere=1988 |orig_lang=English |place=[[United States]] |genre=[[Drama]] |setting=Woods above [[Geneva, Switzerland]] }}
'''''A Walk in the Woods''''' is a 1988 play by [[Lee Blessing]]. The play depicts the developing relationship between two arms limitation negotiators, one Russian and one American, over a year of negotiations.<ref name=NYT/>
==Productions== ''A Walk in the Woods'' was first presented at the [[Yale Repertory Theater]], [[New Haven, Connecticut]], in March 1987. Directed by [[Des McAnuff]] the cast starred [[Josef Sommer]] as the Russian, Andrey Botvinnik and [[Kenneth Welsh]] as the American, John Honeyman.<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=THEATER: BILATERAL TALKS IN 'WALK IN THE WOODS'|first=Mel|last=Gussow|date=March 8, 1987|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/theater/theater-bilateral-talks-in-walk-in-the-woods.html}}</ref> It was next produced at the [[La Jolla Playhouse]], California in July 1987, directed by McAnuff and starring [[Lawrence Pressman]] (as John Honeyman) and [[Michael Constantine]] (as Andrey Botvinnik).<ref name=script>Blessing. Lee. "Introduction. Script". "A Walk in the Woods: A Play in Two Acts", Dramatists Play Service, Inc., 1988, {{ISBN|082221220X}}, p. 3-4</ref>
''A Walk in the Woods'' premiered on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Booth Theatre]] on February 10, 1988 in previews, officially on February 28, 1988, and closed on June 26, 1988 after 21 previews and 137 performances. Directed by Des McAnuff, the cast starred [[Robert Prosky]] as Andrey Botvinnik and [[Sam Waterston]] as John Honeyman.<ref name=vault>[http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/1685/A-Walk-in-the-Woods "'A Walk in the Woods' Broadway"] playbillvault.com, accessed December 18, 2015</ref>
The play was presented at the [[Westport Country Playhouse]], Connecticut, in September 1988. Directed by Maureen F. Gibson, the cast starred Lawrence Pressman (as John Honeyman) and Michael Constantin] (as Andrey Botvinnik).<ref name=klein>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/04/nyregion/theater-walk-in-the-woods-in-westport.html|title=THEATER; 'Walk in the Woods' in Westport|first=Alvin|last=Klein|date=September 4, 1988}}</ref>
The play was produced in the [[West End theatre|West End]] at the Comedy Theater in November 1988. The cast starred [[Alec Guinness]] (Andrey Botvinnik) and [[Edward Herrmann]] (John Honeyman), directed by Ronald Eyre.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/08/24/reviews/guinness-challenges.html|title=Back on Stage, Challenges for Mr. Guinness|first=Herbert|last=Mitgang|year=1989}}</ref><ref>Wolf, Matt. [http://articles.latimes.com/1988-12-12/entertainment/ca-48_1_sir-alec "Sir Alec Was the Force That Lured His Co-Star"] ''Los Angeles Times'', December 12, 1988</ref>
The play was produced [[Off-Broadway]] by the Keen Company at The Clurman Theatre at Theatre Row in September 2014. The cast starred Paul Niebanck (John Honeyman) and [[Kathleen Chalfant]] (as Irina Botvinnik), directed by Jonathan Silverstein.<ref>Purcell, Carey. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/kathleen-chalfant-takes-a-walk-in-the-woods-beginning-sept.-9-329964# "Kathleen Chalfant Takes 'A Walk in the Woods' Beginning Sept. 9"] playbill.com, September 9, 2014</ref> Blessing commented on changing the character of the Soviet diplomat from a man to a woman: " 'I've formally been asked for my approval to change the gender of one or the other negotiator in this play four times, that I recall. In each case I gave it....I think the gender change can wake us up a bit more to a play that discusses issues that haven’t been on the front burner (in quite this way at least) for decades. It reminds us that more and more women are finding their way into our society’s biggest socio-political discussions.' "<ref>McCall, Tulis. [http://www.newyorktheatreguide.com/reviews/walkinthewoods14.htm "reviews. 'A Walk in the Woods'"] newyorktheatreguide.com, October 1, 2014</ref> The character of the Soviet diplomat had previously been played by a woman, in the production at the [[Northern Stage]] in [[Vermont]], which transferred to London at the [[Tricycle Theatre]] in October 2011. Press materials for this production stated "the director's decision to cast a woman in the role keeps the production topical, reflecting the more recent appointments of women such as Madeleine Albright, Condoleezza Rice and Hillary Clinton to positions of diplomatic global power."<ref>Stenton, Mark. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/vermont-production-of-a-walk-in-the-woods-to-visit-londons-tricycle-theatre-181373# Vermont Production of 'A Walk in the Woods' to Visit London's Tricycle Theatre"] playbill.com, August 1, 2011</ref>
==Plot== Two arms negotiators stroll in the woods above [[Geneva, Switzerland]], in the late summer, away from the glare of the negotiating table. They are a Soviet diplomat, Andrey Botvinnik age 57, and John Honeyman age 45, an American negotiator. The two men eventually develop a relationship, although their personalities differ. Botvinnik is friendly and enjoys American culture, Honeyman is formal and idealistic.<ref name=script/>
Note: the play is suggested by a real-life incident, which occurred in 1982. "Negotiators Paul H. Nitze and Yuli A. Kvitsinsky left the official Geneva sessions for an unofficial "walk in the woods" and achieved a breakthrough, soon rejected by their Governments."<ref name=rich>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/29/theater/stage-a-walk-in-the-woods.html|title=Stage: 'A Walk in the Woods'|first=Frank|last=Rich|authorlink=Frank Rich|date=February 29, 1988}}</ref>
==Critical response== [[Frank Rich]], in his review of the Broadway production for ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote: "...as a piece of theater, 'A Walk in the Woods' is the esthetic equivalent of Switzerland, and not only because its setting is 'a pleasant woods on the outskirts of Geneva.' The play at the Booth fudges the distinctions of actual international politics and arms negotiations, choosing instead to telescope the messy, life-or-death conflict into a sentimental relationship between two likable envoys."<ref name=rich/>
Alvin Klein, in reviewing the Westport Country Plahouse production for ''The New York Times'', wrote: "Mr. Blessing's play is a [c]one of ideas, intelligence and some semblance of wit. The dramatic action and character exposition he has provided is negligible. It remains for the actors to establish complete characters and this Mr. Constantine and Mr. Pressman do with immense skill."<ref name=klein/>
==Awards and nominations== The play was nominated for the 1988 [[Tony Award]] , Play and Actor in a Play (Prosky). Prosky won the 1988 Outer Critics Circle Award, Outstanding Actor in a Play.<ref name=vault/>
The play was a finalist for the 1987 [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]].<ref>[http://www.pulitzer.org/bycat/Drama "Pulitzer Prize for Drama, Winners and Finalists"] pulitzer.org, accessed December 18, 2015</ref>
Alec Guinness was nominated for the 1988 [[Olivier Award]], Actor of the Year in a New Play, and the play was nominated as the BBC Award for the Play of the Year<ref>[http://www.olivierawards.com/winners/ "Olivier Awards"] olivierawards.com, accessed December 18, 2015</ref>
==Film adaptation== The play was adapted into a 1988 television film, written by Blessing and directed by [[Kirk Browning]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0461713/ |title=A Walk in the Woods (1988) |publisher=IMDb |accessdate=August 14, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{ibdb title|id=4495|title=A Walk in the Woods}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Walk in the Woods, A}} [[Category:Plays by Lee Blessing]] [[Category:1988 plays]] [[Category:American plays]] [[Category:Two-handers]] [[Category:English-language plays]]

'''Advance-deposit wagering''' (ADW) is a form of [[gambling]] on the outcome of [[horse racing|horse races]] in which bettors must [[Prepayment for service|fund their account]] before being allowed to place bets. ADW is often conducted online or by phone. In contrast to ADW, credit shops allow wagers without advance funding; accounts are settled at month-end. Racetrack owners, horse trainers and state governments sometimes receive a share of ADW revenues.
It typically involves betting on horse or [[greyhound racing]]. Wagering may take place through [[parimutuel betting|parimutuel]] pools.
==Legality==
===Illinois=== Illinois has allowed its adult residents to participate in ADW since 1999 under the Illinois Horse Racing Act of 1975; Illinois receives a cut of ADW revenues.
==Impact== Chapter 58 of the New York State Laws of 2012 added a new Section 911 to the New York State Racing, Pari-Mutuel Wagering and Breeding Law (Racing Law). Section 911 requires the New York State Racing and Wagering Board (Board) to assess the impact of advanced deposit wagering (ADW) in New York State including, but not limited to: * The impact of out-of-state account wagering providers (OSAWP) accepting wagers from New York State residents; * The annual dollar amount wagered by New York State residents through OSAWPs; * The number of OSAWP accounts held by New York State residents; * Information concerning New York State residents who utilize OSAWPs including residency.
Section 911 of the Racing Law required that the study, along with any recommendations, be submitted to the Governor and the Legislature by September 15, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report of Impact of Account Wagering Providers|url=http://www.gaming.ny.gov/pdf/09191215442609.14.12.adwreport.pdf|accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref>
The results of the survey revealed that New York residents bet $165,567,707 in 2010 and $142,246,859 YTD 9/30/11 through the responding OSAWPs. This includes wagering on the New York racing product and on out-of-state racetracks. Table 1 provides detail of the handle by New York racetracks and out-of-state racetracks. The Board estimates this handle will exceed $200,000,000 in 2012.
The survey also showed that OSAWPs listed 18,769 accounts in 2010 and 21,310 accounts in YTD 9/30 2011 as New York resident accounts. All 62 New York State counties are represented. Table 2 lists the number of accounts by the county in which the zip code originated. Table 2-A lists the number of accounts by statutorily defined Off-Track Betting Regions. NJ Account Wagering, Sol Mutuel, Global Wagering Solutions and Elite Turf Club reported having no New York accounts.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = American Pie Presents: The Book of Love | image = The book of love.jpg | caption = DVD cover | image size = 190px | director = [[John Putch]] | producer = Mike Elliot | writer = [[David H. Jennifer Holland
John Patrick Jordan
[[Louisa Lytton]]

[[Rosanna Arquette]]
[[Eugene Levy]] | music = [[David Nessim Lawrence|David Lawrence]] | cinematography = Ross Berryman | editing = [[John Gilbert (film editor)|John Gilbert]] | studio = Capital Arts Entertainment | distributor = [[Universal Studios]] | released = {{dts|2009|12|22}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $7 million | gross = $5,021,219{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/American-Pie-Book-of-Love|title=American Pie Presents: The Book of Love – DVD Sales|publisher=The Numbers|accessdate=16 April 2018}} }} '''''American Pie Presents: The Book of Love''''' is a 2009 American [[sex comedy film]] released by [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]]. It is the fourth and final installment in [[American Pie Presents (film series)|''American Pie Presents'' film series]], a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of the [[American Pie (film series)|''American Pie'' franchise]]. The film stars [[Bug Hall]], John Patrick Jordan, Kevin M. Horton, [[Brandon Hardesty]], and [[Eugene Levy]]. This was [[Sherman Hemsley]]'s final film appearance before his death on July 24, 2012. ''American Pie Presents: The Book of Love'' was released [[direct-to-video|direct-to-DVD]] in the United States on December 22, 2009. ==Plot== {{Long plot|date=March 2018}} The film begins with Rob entering his bedroom, and attempting to masturbate with a peanut butter and jelly sandwich (similar to the apple pie scenario in the first film). While he is doing this his dog, Frizzie, tries to eat the sandwich, and Rob's little brother Cody takes a video of the ordeal. Later, Rob meets with his friends, Nathan and Marshall Lube, at school. Nathan reveals that his girlfriend, Dana, has pledged to abstain from sex until marriage despite the fact that she has already slept with six other people. Rob talks to Heidi, a girl he is attracted to, and Stifler. Stifler states that if Rob doesn't make a move on Heidi, he will. In class, Lube has a vivid fantasy about a group of cheerleaders, particularly one named Ashley Lawrence. Rob and Heidi meet later in the school library where she discloses that she is a virgin, and wishes to just "get it [sex] over with". At the school dance, Nathan tries to get to second base with Dana, but only manages to offend her due to her abstinence pledge. Rob attempts to tell Heidi how he feels about her but is interrupted by Nathan and Lube. He eventually finds her in the library about to have sex with another student, and drops a lit candle in a bin in shock. This sets the library on fire, which sets off the water sprinklers. The next day, when Rob and Heidi are cleaning the library, Rob finds a secret compartment containing 'The Bible' (The Book of Love). He shows the book to Nathan and Lube and explains that it is a sex manual that has been compiled over forty years by the students who found it. The book is regarded as legendary, but unfortunately has been damaged by the water. Later in the local mall, Rob attempts to test a tip in the book; 'Simple Flattery'. He approaches Ashley in a lingerie store and complements her. Ashley leads him into a changing room, takes off her bra and top, and makes him steal a bra for her. Unfortunately Rob is caught and forced to pay with his mom's credit card. Meanwhile, Nathan goes to Dana's church service to talk to her, but accidentally broadcasts the explicit and highly personal conversation to the entire congregation on the church's PA system. Dana's father then bans her from seeing Nathan. When she receives her credit card bill, Rob's mom tries to talk to him about it, prompting Rob to sarcastically say that he likes wearing women's underwear. He is again filmed by his little brother, who again posts the footage on the internet for the whole school to see. The next day, Heidi, Imogen, and Dana are at a school basketball game in which Rob and Stifler are playing. A girl called Katie tries to talk to Stifler, but he brushes her off. Rob again attempts to tell Heidi how he feels, but is unable to. Lube discovers a page in The Bible which tells of a brothel in Canada and a prostitute, Monique, who is very experienced. The entry was written in 1975, but Lube misreads the date as 1995, and they decide to visit. When they meet Monique the boys are disgusted, but Nathan states that they should go for it anyway. Nathan and Lube make Rob go first, but Monique dies while performing oral sex on him. They panic and drive back to the USA. Rob and Heidi are once again in the library where Rob finally tells her he is attracted to her. Heidi feels the same, and they agree to meet at Stifler's party later. At the party Heidi hears Rob shout "Tonight, I'm getting laid!", and runs upstairs. Stifler again brushes off Katie when she tries to talk to him. Lube tells Ashley how he feels about her and guarantees sexual satisfaction, but she still turns him down. Ashley's friend is impressed with his promise and tells Lube to meet her upstairs, but when she finds an offensive text on his phone she storms out. Nathan attempts to reconcile with Dana but offends her, making her leave once again. Rob finds Heidi in bed with Stifler and leaves the room. Heidi follows him downstairs, but Rob refuses to talk to her and begins to drink heavily. He declares "only assholes get laid!" and then behaves crudely to a random girl, who promptly goes to bed with him. She asks him to have sex with her from behind, but he hallucinates and sees Heidi saying; "You aren't seriously going to stick your dick in that, are you?". Rob then throws up on the girl's back. The next morning his mother asks him if he drove home drunk, and shows him a film she received on her phone of Rob throwing up on the girl the night before. In an attempt to restore The Bible, Rob and his friends resolve to find all of the people who originally wrote it in order to recreate it, starting with the original creator, Noah Levenstein. They eventually succeed in recreating the book. Rob and his friends then go on the school ski trip. In a log cabin where a few students are playing strip poker, Katie again attempts to talk to Stifler, who again brushes her off. She bets Stifler that if she wins at poker he has to apologise to her and run naked in the snow. Stifler loses and is forced to apologise and go outside naked, where he is humped by a moose. Due to last night's ordeal, Imogen keeps him company and the two form a bond. The other students are riding up the mountain in gondola ski lifts, but Nathan has sex with Dana in the lift control room and accidentally shut off the lifts' power. In one lift, Rob and Heidi reconcile and kiss. Ashley and Lube are in another lift, where Lube falls out when trying to go for help. When Ashley climbs down to him, Lube tells her how he really feels about her, moving her to tears. Heidi and Rob return to the cabin and have sex. Lube and Ashley do the same. The story ends with Rob, Nathan, and Lube returning the newly restored Bible to where Rob found it, after Rob has added his signature to it. As a finale, Rob's brother, Cody, enters his bedroom to find an online film of him putting a vacuum cleaner on his penis. To his horror it has been viewed almost 10 million times. Rob ends the film with the words "Gotcha, ha ha". ==Cast== {{col-begin|width=auto}} {{col-break}} * [[Bug Hall]] as Robert "Rob" Shearson * [[Brandon Hardesty]] as Marshall "Lube" Lubetsky * Kevin M. Horton as Nathan Jenkyll * [[Beth Behrs]] as Heidi * [[Melanie Papalia]] as Dana * Jennifer Holland as Ashley Lawrence * John Patrick Jordan as [[List of characters in the American Pie film series#Scott Stifler|Scott Stifler]] * [[Louisa Lytton]] as Imogen * [[Sherman Hemsley]] as Pastor * [[Curtis Armstrong]] as Pete O'Donnell * [[Jim Wynorski]] as Eddie * [[Rosanna Arquette]] as Madeline Shearson * [[Eugene Levy]] as [[List of characters in the American Pie film series#Noah Levenstein|Noah Levenstein]] * [[Cindy Busby]] as Amy * Naomi Hewer as Alyson * Adrienne Carter as Katie * Nico McEown as Cody * Edwin Perez as Gibbs {{col-break|gap=2em}} ;Cameo Appearances * [[Kevin Federline]] as Canadian Border Guard * [[Dustin Diamond]] as Alumnus Guy #1 * [[C. Thomas Howell]] as Alumnus Guy #2 * [[Christopher Knight (actor)|Christopher Knight]] as Alumnus Guy #3 * [[Tim Matheson]] as Carlito (Alumnus Guy #4) * [[Steve Railsback]] as Alumnus Guy #5 * [[Robert Romanus]] as Alumnus Guy #6 * [[Bret Michaels]] as himself {{col-end}} ==Production== ''The Book of Love'' was filmed in [[Vancouver]]. The East Great Falls High was actually [[Centennial Secondary School (Coquitlam)|Centennial Secondary School]] in [[Coquitlam, British Columbia]]. The tram scene up the mountain is located at [[Vancouver]]'s [[Grouse Mountain]]. ==Soundtrack== {{div col}} # "[[Oh Yeah (Yello song)|Oh Yeah]]" by [[Yello]] # "[[Something in Your Mouth]]" by [[Nickelback]] # "Sexy Little Thing"/"Miss Cindy" by The High Decibels # "Smoke Alarm" by Freddy Rawsh # "[[Hot N Cold]]" by [[Katy Perry]] # "[[Dance, Dance (Fall Out Boy song)|Dance, Dance]]" by [[Fall Out Boy]] # "Turn It Down" by Sideway Runners # "Hypnotik" by Roobie Breastnut # "Beer" by Ace Baker # "How Do I Know" by Wanda Bell # "When You Want Some Uh Uh" by Nio Renee Wilson # "Get Loose (NipJoint Remix)" by [[Quanteisha]] # "Pauline" by The High Lonesome # "Katmandu" by Sam Morrison # "1969" by Dr. Hollywood # "Body Language" by [[Isaac Hayes]] # "If Something's Wrong" by Aidan Hawken # "Damned If I Do Ya (Damned If I Don't)" by [[All Time Low]] # "[[Hot Mess (Cobra Starship song)|Hot Mess]]" by [[Cobra Starship]] # "Are You Ready" [[Crash Boom Bang]] # "Got Me Some Love" by Keely Hawkes # "Army Girl" by The Genders # "Obsession" by Ace Baker # "Something Wild" by The High Lonesome # "Burnin' Love" by Travis Tritt # "Laid" by Aidan Hawken # "She Can Dance" by Billy Trudel # "Monday" by Mikey and the Gypsys # "In It for You" ("Catch My Fall") by The Elliots # "Heartbeats" by Melinda Ortner # "[[Say Yes (Elliott Smith song)|Say Yes]]" by [[Elliott Smith]] # "Book of Love" by Powderfinger # "Sinner" by Big B featuring Scott Russo # "Mouth to Mouth" by [[Kaya Jones]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} {{Portal|Film in the United States|Sexuality|Comedy|2000s}} * {{IMDb title|1407050}} * {{Allrovi movie|503962}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|american_pie_presents_the_book_of_love}} {{American Pie}} {{John Putch}} {{DEFAULTSORT:American Pie Presents: The Book Of Love}} [[Category:2009 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:American Pie (series)]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in Vancouver]] [[Category:Direct-to-video sequel films]] [[Category:Films about virginity]] [[Category:Cheerleading films]] [[Category:American teen comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures direct-to-video films]] [[Category:Films directed by John Putch]]

{{Expand Hebrew|date=April 2011|הילדים של ארנה}} {{Infobox film | name = Arna's Children | image = Arnas-children.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Juliano Mer Khamis]]
[[Danniel Danniel]] | producer = Osnat Trabelsi
Pieter van Huystee | writer = | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2004|04|20|One World Film Festival}} | runtime = 84 minutes | country = Israel
Netherlands | language = Arabic
Hebrew | budget = | gross = }} '''''Arna's Children''''' is a 2004 Dutch-Israeli [[documentary film]] directed by [[Juliano Mer Khamis]] and [[Danniel Danniel]]. The film's story revolves around a children's theater group in [[Jenin]] in the [[Palestinian territories]] established by [[Arna Mer-Khamis]], the director's mother, an Israeli Jewish political and human rights activist. The film portrays the lives of [[Arna Mer-Khamis]] and the children members of the theater including Ala el-Sabagr, [[Zakaria Zubeidi]], Daud Zubeidi, Majdi Shadi, [http://empathy-for-peace.org/meet-the-team/ Haifa Staiti], Nidal Swetti, Yussef Swetti, Mahmoud Kaneri, Khairia Fakhri and Ashraf Abu-Alheji.{{cite web|title=Arna's Children (2004)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0408504/|publisher=imdb.com|accessdate=23 November 2013}}{{cite web|last=DARGIS|first=MANOHLA|title=Young Voices From the Front Lines|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/08/movies/08ARNA.html?_r=0|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=23 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=Arna's Children|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/arnas-children|publisher=metacritic.com|accessdate=23 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=Arna's Children (2003)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/arnas_children/|publisher=rottentomatoes.com|accessdate=23 November 2013}} The film won "Best Documentary Feature" in the 2004 [[Tribeca Film Festival]]. Three of the theater children died in various operations or while resisting the Israeli army, namely Ala, Nidal, and Ashraf. Yussef committed a suicide attack in [[Hadera]] in 2001, murdering four civilians. Two other children, Daud and Zakaria were imprisoned. The director of the film [[Juliano Mer Khamis]] was assassinated in [[Jenin]] on 4 April 2011 by masked militants. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051224052037/http://www.arna.info/Arna/movie.php Film website] *[http://www.cultureunplugged.com/play/4981/Arna-s-Children Culture Unplugged] * {{IMDb title|0408504|Arna's Children}} [[Category:2004 films]] [[Category:Arabic-language films]] [[Category:Hebrew-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Children's theatre]] [[Category:Participant Media films]] {{poli-documentary-film-stub}} {{theatre-stub}}

page.title: Australian and New Zealand television frequencies

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{lead rewrite|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} '''Television frequency allocation''' has evolved since the start of television in Australia in 1956, and later in New Zealand in 1960. There was no coordination between the national spectrum management authorities in either country to establish the frequency allocations. The management of the spectrum in both countries is largely the product of their economical and political situation. New Zealand didn't start to develop television service until 1965 due to World War 2 and its economic harm in the country's economy. The demand and planning for television in Australia intensified after WW2, with the Chifley government first favouring the existing British model (state monopoly) in 1948, and New Zealand used a similar model during the introduction of television in the 1960s. Private broadcasting did not come to the country until the 1980s, but there was no spectrum expansion to cope with the new arrangement. == History== ===Australia === Australian television broadcasting commenced in 1956 in Melbourne and Sydney to coincide with the 1956 Summer Olympics. Three stations commenced operations on a ten channel spectrum arrangement: the ABC operating in the VHF low band (VHF Ch 2), and the commercial stations operating in the VHF high band (VHF Ch 7 & 9). At the outset, commercial stations were independently owned, but due to economic forces network affiliations were soon established. This pattern of television spectrum allocation was replicated in most of the state capital cities over the subsequent decade, with the exception of Hobart (one commercial service on VHF 6) and eventually Darwin (both the ABC and the commercial service were allocated in the VHF high band). Geographical conditions differed in Melbourne and Sydney. The Melbourne transmission towers were located on the nearby Mount Dandenong, and their elevation and broadcasting power on an otherwise relatively flat terrain meant that the broadcasting signal could be reached for some considerable distance, although there were some areas that experienced reception difficulties due to hills or buildings. In the Sydney "basin" (formed by the [[Blue Mountains (New South Wales)|Blue Mountains]]) the broadcast towers were collocated on the original studio sites, and given the undulating geography of Sydney there were many areas that experienced reception difficulties. The Blue Mountain terrain in the West of Sydney meant that capital city broadcasting did not penetrate into the hinterland of NSW, unlike that of Melbourne. It is possible that the penetration of weak signals into the Victorian hinterlands hastened the demand for the establishment of regional television stations, which commenced in 1961. The Australian Government restricted regional television broadcasting to one commercial service and a repeater station of the national broadcaster from the capital city ABC station. Regional television stations tended to be allocated to VHF 6, 8 or in some cases 10. === New Zealand === In popular culture, there is a TV series "50 Years of New Zealand Television" that covers in Episode 1 some of the early difficulties of getting TV broadcasting started in NZ, but with no coverage at all with respect to Frequency Allocation. New Zealand for all practical purposes did not get television broadcasting of any kind until around 1960, when a Pay TV system was allowed to operate in Auckland. The existing documentaries on TV development in NZ don't cover Frequency Allocation * [https://www.nzonscreen.com/title/compass-first-five-years-of-television-1966 The First 5 Years of Television] * [https://www.nzonscreen.com/title/network-new-zealand-1985 Network New Zealand] * [https://www.nzonscreen.com/title/25-years-of-television-1985 25 Years of Television] * [https://www.nzonscreen.com/title/50-years-of-new-zealand-television-episode-one-2010 50 Years of NZ Television] === FM allocation artifacts === The United Kingdom and New Zealand until recently shared an FM broadcasting allocation of 88.0 MHz to 105.0 MHz. Since the early 2000s both nations have full use of the standard FM Stereo region due to reallocation activities related to their separate implementation strategies for digital television. This smaller FM Band allocation (less than 20 MHz : 88 MHz to 108 MHz—typical of FM in the rest of the world) can be traced to the 405 line system's VHF allocation block. The UK adopted the 405 line system but NZ did not. The slightly smaller allocation only posed problems for the UK for its densely populated metropolitan regions, but NZ had few problems with the smaller allocation. NZ's allocation for FM remained smaller as if NZ had adopted the 405 line system. New Zealand considered adopting the 405 line system in the late 1950s to early 1960s but adopted PAL instead. This impacted the frequency allocation block for FM broadcasting making it smaller. New Zealand's FM frequency allocation issue was not fixed until the late 1990s, when the FM band was expanded to the standard full 20 MHz block. As of the mid-2010s NZ totally abandoned its VHF band for UHF channels above 25. ==Differences in frequencies == There is a frequency offset for many DTV channels between Australia and NZ, because of historical reasons relating to the introduction of PAL. * Both Australia and New Zealand use 7 MHz channel spacing (for PAL B) on VHF, but the frequencies and channel numbers differ substantially because of Australia revising its VHF TV band usage. * Australia adopted [[Zweiton]] for stereophonic audio broadcasting, whilst NZ adopted [[NICAM]]. * For PAL, the only difference is the placement of the [[NICAM]] carrier vs the [[Zweiton]] carrier, for broadcasters using [[NICAM]]. NZ used 5.824 MHz NICAM carrier offset, as used in mainland Europe. * Australia's Zweiton offset was not changed with respect to the European standard. * Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Papua New Guinea have the same UHF band allocation for TV broadcasting. ===Obsolete channels=== * With the introduction of [[digital terrestrial television]] in Australia in 2001, channels 10 and 11 were moved up by 1 MHz. ** This allocation change allowed a full 7 MHz for a new channel (9A). ** VHF channel 12 was added following the new channel 11 to compensate for the change. * channels 0-2 and 5A ceased to be used for television when analogue television broadcasting was discontinued. * Television broadcasts on channels 3, 4, and 5 were previously discontinued in most regional areas in 1991 and 1992. Since the frequencies for these channels overlapped the range used for FM radio, any television broadcasts on these channels prevented the allocation of new FM radio licences, predominantly in regional areas. * VHF Low Band DX using ITU TV Band (I) and part of Band (III) from NZ may disappear with the transition to DVB-T. ==Frequency allocation table== DVB-T channel allocation note * The allocation for terrestrial television must be seen in terms of uniform system G 8 MHz blocks (for bands IV and V in NZ) and system B 7 MHz blocks (for bands I to V in Australia) after the cessation of analogue television. * DVB-T, analogue systems B and G utilize the same 250 kHz guard-band. * After analogue television transmissions have ceased, only the preferred main carrier wave centre frequency should be listed as [[QAM (television)|QAM]] modulates all AV channels and other data into a single [[H.222]] data stream. * Digital services on channels above Ch 51 are going to change channel after the analog services are switched off. The ACMA has published the pre-stack and post-stack channel in a spreadsheet on its website. * Australian channel 12 was discontinued decades ago but is being reintroduced with digital television, generally for the [[ABC Television|ABC]] in the major metropolitan areas. * A common problem (for metropolitan areas in particular) of difficulty receiving digital 10 (on channel 11) and digital ABC (on channel 12) is because older antennas were not designed to receive channels 11 and 12. Many VHF Band III antennas were only designed to receive channels 6 to 10 for analog television transmissions.{{cite web|title=Digital television services on Channel 12 |url=http://www.digitalready.gov.au/Content/Documents/Brochure-and-info-sheets/National/Digital-television-services-on-Channel-12.aspx |publisher=Australian Government |date=August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018105327/http://www.digitalready.gov.au/Content/Documents/Brochure-and-info-sheets/National/Digital-television-services-on-Channel-12.aspx |archivedate=18 October 2012 |df=dmy }} * Australia and New Zealand analog sub-carriers use the standard B/G offsets from the vision carrier. ** [[PAL]] color difference at +4.43361875 MHz ** FM monaural full mixed down channel audio at +5.5 MHz ** New Zealand (B/G version) [[NICAM]] stereo or dual monaural at +5.824 MHz ** Australian [[A2 Stereo]] right or second monaural channel at +5.742 MHz (AM signalling at +5.46875 MHz) == DTT allocation == Table notes : Text in ''italics'' means these frequencies are not currently used but set aside as a Guardband or for future use. {| class="wikitable" ! rowspan="2"|'''[[Radio frequency|RF]]

{{short description|album by Onyx}} {{Infobox album | name = Bacdafucup: Part II | type = [[Album]] | artist = [[Onyx (group)|Onyx]] | cover = Backdafucup_part_II.jpg | alt = | released = July 9, 2002 ([[United States|US]]) | recorded = 2001-2002 | venue = | studio = OPM Studios ([[Los Angeles]], [[California]]) | genre = [[East Coast hip hop]], [[Gangsta Rap]], [[Hardcore Hip Hop]] | length = 48:58 | label = [[Koch Records]] | producer = Davinci
DR Period
[[Havoc (musician)|Havoc]]
Self
Ant Boogie
Co-Stars
[[Scott Storch]]
Fredro Starr (executive)
Sticky Fingaz (executive)
Omar "Iceman" Sharif (executive) | prev_title = [[Shut 'Em Down (album)|Shut 'Em Down]] | prev_year = 1998 | next_title = [[Triggernometry]] | next_year = 2003 | misc = {{Singles | name = Bacdafucup: Part II | type = Studio | single1 = Hold Up | single1date = 2002 | single2 = Big Trucks/Bring 'Em Out Dead | single2date = 2002 | single3 = Slam Harder/Hold Up | single3date = 2002 | single4 = Slam Harder/Bring 'Em Out Dead | single4date = 2002 }}}} '''''Bacdafucup: Part II''''' is the fourth album from rap group [[Onyx (group)|Onyx]], released on July 9, 2002 by [[Koch Records]]. The album was produced by Davinci, DR Period, [[Havoc (musician)|Havoc]], Self, Ant Boogie, Co-Stars, [[Scott Storch]]. The album features appearances by American rappers X1, Still Livin', Versatile, Platinum Plus, Felisa Marisol. ''Bacdafucup: Part II'' debuted at number 46 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], number 11 on the [[Top R&B/Hip Hop Albums]] and number 2 on the [[Top Independent Albums]] chart. == Background == ''Bacdafucup: Part II'' is the first album released by Onyx after the group left [[Def Jam]]. Onyx returns after [[Sticky Fingaz]], [[Fredro Starr]] and [[Sonny Seeza]] took time off to do solo albums and become film stars. Onyx made a deal with [[Koch Records]] to release one album and came back with the sequel to their very successful debut LP ''[[Bacdafucup]]''. Onyx reunited for ''Bacdafucup: Part II''.{{Cite web| url= https://www.laweekly.com/music/black-metal-yoga-and-black-metal-brunch-bring-the-genre-into-the-lifestyle-events-arena-9720335|title=The Top 20 Rap Album Sequels of All Time| website=laweekly.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} The album cover even echoes that of the debut, although only the three remaining members of Onyx are featured on the new album.{{Cite web| url= https://hiphopisntdead.blogspot.com/2014/07/onyx-bacdafucup-part-ii-july-2-2002.html|title=Onyx - Bacdafucup: Part II (July 22, 2002)| website=hiphopisntdead.blogspot.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} The album consisting of 12 new tracks and included a return to their biggest hit with "Slam Harder", DR Period track uses a clever sample of the theme song from the TV show "[[Welcome Back, Kotter]]" to introduce the song and provide melody throughout.{{Cite web| url= http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2002_07_bacup2.html|title=Onyx :: Bacdafucup Part II (Review by Steve 'Flash' Juon)| website=rapreviews.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} However, "Slam Harder" is censored on the album when the rest of the LP is explicit. The song "Feel Me" was recorded on the night of [[September 11, 2001]] and dedicated to the events that happened that day in the USA.{{Cite web| url= http://www.mvremix.com/urban/interviews/stickyfingaz.shtml|title=Sticky Fingaz (Onyx) - conducted by Todd E. Jones| website=mvremix.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} == Singles == Four singles from this album were released: "Hold Up", "Big Trucks/Bring 'Em Out Dead", "Slam Harder/Hold Up" and "Slam Harder/Bring 'Em Out Dead" ==Critical response== {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[Rate Your Music]] |rev1Score = {{rating|2.60|5}} [https://rateyourmusic.com/release/album/onyx/bacdafucup-part-ii Rate Your Music Review] |rev2 = [[AllMusic]] |rev2Score = {{rating|3.0|5}} [https://www.allmusic.com/album/bacdafucup-pt-ii-mw0000658877/releases AllMusic Review] |rev3 = RapReviews |rev3score = {{Rating|5|10}}[http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2002_07_bacup2.html RapReviews review] |rev4 = MVRemix |rev4Score = {{Rating|5.5|10}}[http://www.mvremix.com/urban/reviews/2002/onyx2.shtml MVRemix Review] |rev5 = RapArtAge |rev5Score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}[http://rapartage.narod.ru/reviews/rev_onyx_bacdafucup2.htm RapArtAge Review] |rev6 = [[Sputnikmusic]] |rev6Score = {{rating|2.4|5}} [https://www.sputnikmusic.com/soundoff.php?albumid=49504 Sputnikmusic Review] |rev7 = Oocities |rev7Score = {{rating|4.5|10}} [http://www.oocities.org/trizoy99/reviews/bacdafucup2.html Oocities Review] }} ''Bacdafucup: Part II'' came a decade later, and the passion and energy behind it wasn't nearly as believeable as it was back in the early 1990s.{{Cite web| url= https://www.complex.com/music/2013/09/rap-album-sequels/onyx-bacdafucup|title=A History of Rap Album Sequels (by Chris Yuscavage)| website=complex.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} Onyx claims they're back, but not in the form we expected them to be in. They should have thought about what they were naming this LP before it was released, because with this title, many had high expectations, it's nowhere near being a complete travesty. Is this album commercial? More than one may expect.{{Cite web| url= https://rateyourmusic.com/release/album/onyx/bacdafucup-part-ii-3/|title=Bacdafucup Part II| website=rateyourmusic.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} This LP has gotten horrible reviews by critics as well as die hard Onyx fans. After the incredible Sticky Fingaz solo album or the last very dense Onyx LP ("[[Shut 'Em Down (album)|Shut 'Em Down]]"), this album does seem somewhat lazy and sloppy.{{Cite web| url= http://www.mvremix.com/urban/reviews/2002/onyx2.shtml|title=Onyx - Bacdafucup Part II (review by NewJeruPoet)| website=mvremix.com |access-date=2018-08-15}} ==Accolades== In 2012 in the Russian version of the magazine [[GQ]] rapper [https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Влади_(рэпер) Влади] commented on the choice of favorite CDs [https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Корж,_Макс Макса Коржа], among which was the album Onyx ''Bacdafucup: Part II''.{{Cite web| url= https://www.gq.ru/lifestyle/vybor-maksa-korzha-ocenka-vladi|title=ВЫБОР МАКСА КОРЖА: ОЦЕНКА ВЛАДИ| website=laweekly.com |access-date=2018-11-11}} In 2013 [[Complex (magazine)|Complex]] put the album in their list ''A History of Rap Album Sequels''.{{Cite web| url= https://www.complex.com/music/2013/09/rap-album-sequels/|title=A History of Rap Album Sequels (by Chris Yuscavage) [September 18, 2013]| website=complex.com |access-date=2018-11-11}} In 2015 [[LA Weekly]] put the album in their list ''The Top 20 Rap Album Sequels of All Time''.{{Cite web| url= https://www.laweekly.com/music/the-top-20-rap-album-sequels-of-all-time-5731177|title=The Top 20 Rap Album Sequels of All Time (by CHAZ KANGAS) [JULY 6, 2015]| website=laweekly.com |access-date=2018-11-11}} {|class="wikitable" |- ! Publication ! Country ! Accolade ! Year ! Rank |- |''[[GQ]]'' |rowspan=1|[[Russia]] |''ВЫБОР МАКСА КОРЖА: ОЦЕНКА ВЛАДИ'' |2012 | style="text-align:center;"|* |- |''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' |rowspan=2|[[United States]] |''A History of Rap Album Sequels'' |2013 | style="text-align:center;"|* |- |''LA Weekly'' |''The Top 20 Rap Album Sequels of All Time'' |2015 | style="text-align:center;"|19 |- |} ==Track listing== {| class="wikitable" |- ! # ! track ! featured guest(s) ! producer(s) ! sample(s) ! length |- | 01. | "What's Onyx" | | Davinci | | 2:57 |- | 02. | "Bring 'Em Out Dead" | | DR Period | | 3:44 |- | 03. | "Slam Harder" | Versatile | DR Period | *"Welcome Back" by John Sebastian (1976) | 4:38 |- | 04. | "Hold Up" | X1 | [[Havoc (musician)|Havoc]] | | 4:03 |- | 05. | "Bang 2 Dis" | | Davinci | | 4:06 |- | 06. | "Gangsta" | X1, Platinum Plus | DR Period | | 4:19 |- | 07. | "Hood Beef" | X1, Still Livin' | Self | | 3:40 |- | 08. | "Big Trucks" | | DR Period | | 4:58 |- | 09. | "Clap And Rob 'Em" | Versatile | Ant Boogie | *"Rockin' Robin" by Bobby Day (1958) | 3:15 |- | 10. | "Onyx Is Back" | Felisa Marisol | CoStars | *"Fat Boys Are Back" by Fat Boys (1985) | 3:32 |- | 11. | "Feel Me" | | Davinci | | 5:32 |- | 12. | "Wet The Club" | | [[Scott Storch]] | | 4:14 |- |} ===US edition bonus tracks=== # "Hold Up (DJ Infinite Mix)" - 3:54 # "V-12"  (Produced by Davinci) - 4:01 ===Japanese edition bonus tracks=== # "Hold Up (Remix)" - 3:54 ==Chart positions== {| class="wikitable" ! In '''[[Israel]]''', [[baseball]] is a sport that is not extremely popular, although many initiatives are in place to help develop and grow the sport in Israel. There are approximately 1,000 baseball players in Israel in 16 cities across the country. Volunteer coaches and donors are instrumental to the growth and development of the sport as baseball resources are very limited within the country. Israel is currently ranked 19th in the world in the sport.<ref>[http://www.wbsc.org/rankings WBSC Rankings NOV. 2018] - Retrieved 28 NOV., 2018</ref>
==History== {{See also|History of baseball outside the United States#Israel|l1=History of baseball outside the United States}} Baseball was first played in the [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate of Palestine]] on July 4, 1927.<ref name=rechist>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713064314/http://www.israelbaseballleague.com/baseballinisrael/recenthistory/|title=israelbaseballleague.com: Recent History|publisher=www.israelbaseballleague.com|accessdate=June 16, 2008}}</ref> The first field in Israel was built in Kibbutz Gezer in 1979, and the country now has a baseball field at the [[Yarkon Sports Complex]] in [[Petah Tikva|Petach Tikva]]. Israel sends national teams of various age groups to international baseball tournaments each year. The best recent showing to date in International Play (Pool A) was a 1st place by the Israeli Juvenile (ages 10–12) in the 2009 European Championships (CEB). Between 500 and 1,000 Israelis regularly play baseball in amateur league play. Baseball is growing at an accelerated pace, with much greater baseball identity associated with the country.<ref>[http://www.israelemb.org/US-Israel-Relations/sports.html Embassy of Israel].</ref>
==Israel Association of Baseball== The Israel Association of Baseball (IAB), established in 1986, is a non-profit organization in Israel. Their goal is to promote and develop baseball in Israel. In order to accomplish this they teach baseball to youth, organize national tournaments as well as aid in assisting Israeli teams to compete internationally, and procuring the required equipment. Additionally they will help organize the league, ensure they have a proper field, train the coaches, umpires and player.<ref>http://www.ibaf.org/en/nation/ebcc9784-ed5b-4471-8b1b-42fb474e9511</ref>
The IAB is a member of The [[Olympic Committee of Israel]], The [[Confederation of European Baseball]] and The International Baseball Association. The above organization in addition to the Israel Sports Authority, recognizes the IAB as the sole governing body for baseball in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball.org.il/|title=IAB - Israel Association of Baseball - Home|website=www.baseball.org.il}}</ref>
Notable players to play in the IAB include [[Alon Leichman]] and [[Dean Kremer]].
The following clubs are registered to participate in the IAB; these are mostly youth clubs (Senior teams have a star next to their name:) * Bet Shemesh Blue Sox * Bet Shemesh Comets * Bet Shemesh Mavericks * Gezer Bats * Ginot Shomron Wild Boars * Hashmonaim Aztec Flames * Jerusalem Lions* * Lev Hasharon Nationals * Modiin Miracles* * Ra'anana Raiders* * Rehovot Raptors * Tel Aviv Comrades* * Zofit Warriors
==Israel Baseball Academy== Under the authority of the IAB the Israel Baseball Academy launched in October 2014.<ref name=jpbb>[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Sports/First-Israel-baseball-academy-could-be-a-real-game-changer-380221 First Israel baseball academy could be a real game-changer] - Retrieved 30 October 2014</ref> The first year's program started in mid-October at [[Yarkon Sports Complex]] in [[Petah Tikva]].<ref name=jpbb />
Academy players will partake in weekly training. This will give them the opportunities to play in the Israel National Team Program, to be recognized as Elite Athletes in the IDF. The program is also recognized by [[Major League Baseball]] and will give them access to programs designed for the best young players in Europe.<ref name=bb>[http://www.baseball.org.il/en/cat-heb-2/264-the-first-israel-baseball-academy-has-begun The First Israel Baseball Academy has Begun] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923182454/http://www.baseball.org.il/en/cat-heb-2/264-the-first-israel-baseball-academy-has-begun |date=2015-09-23 }} - Retrieved 30 October 2014</ref>
Former IAB National Director Nate Fish and National Team Coach David Schenker were the first coaches for the academy. [[Dan Rothem]], a former college pitcher and Israel National Team player will be the pitching coach.<ref name=bb /> Each year the program plans to include 10 kids age 14-21.<ref name=bb /> In addition to the first year's participants there are 20 kids which are being scouted for year two.<ref name=bb />
There are currently 24 players aged 14-18 in the Israel Baseball Academy. National Coach, Ryan Willen, a former catcher at division 3 Washinton & Jefferson College runs the Academy. Additionally, former Japanese professional coach and player by the nickname of "KAZ" assists in operating and maintaining the high-level product offered to the nations best players.
==Israel Baseball League== {{See also|Israel Baseball League}} In 2007, the Israel Baseball League played its one and only season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Israel_Baseball_League|title=Israel Baseball League - BR Bullpen|website=www.baseball-reference.com}}</ref> The six league teams were the [[Tel Aviv Lightning]], [[Netanya Tigers]], [[Bet Shemesh Blue Sox]], [[Petach Tikva Pioneers]], [[Modi'in Miracle]], and [[Ra'anana Express]].<ref>http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1164881960205 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813162101/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull&cid=1164881960205 |date=2011-08-13 }}</ref> All the leagues games were played at three [[ballpark]]s. The [[Yarkon Sports Complex]], [[Gezer Field]], and Sportek Baseball Field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jstandard.com/content/item/This_fan_had_a_ball/|title=This fan had a ball|publisher=}}</ref>
In November 2007 it was announced that a new six-team league, the Israel Professional Baseball League, was taking shape, and would play its first season in 2008. Those behind the new league included billionaire Jeffrey Rosen, a major IBL investor who also owns the [[Maccabi Haifa B.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] basketball team, which he bought in the summer of 2007, and is the chairman of Triangle Financial Services of [[Aventura, Florida]]; Andrew Wilson, who was a facilitator on the ground for the IBL and now works for Rosen; Alan Gardner, a lawyer from New York, who was the centerfielder for the Bet Shemesh Blue Sox; and Michael Rollhaus, a businessman from Queens and major IBL investor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c41_a1081/News/Short_Takes.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080221162607/http://www.thejewishweek.com/viewArticle/c41_a1081/News/Short_Takes.html |archivedate=2008-02-21 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/932135.html|title=Sports Shorts – Haaretz – Israel News<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref>
==World Baseball Classic== {{main|Israel at the World Baseball Classic}}
===2013 Tournament=== Israel, was placed in the [[2013 World Baseball Classic – Qualifier 1|Qualifier 1]] bracket with [[Spain]], [[South Africa]] and [[France]].
Israel competed in their first [[2013 World Baseball Classic – Qualification|qualifying match]] for the 2013 tournament on 19 September 2012. In this game they defeated South Africa by a score of 7-3. [[Nate Freiman]] had two home runs in the victory.<ref>http://web.worldbaseballclassic.com/wbc/2013/video/play.jsp?content_id=24911733&topic_id=41680128&c_id=mlb</ref>
Israel's second qualifying match was against Spain on 21 September 2012. Israel won the game by a score of 4-2. Nate Freiman once again homered twice for Israel in the victory.<ref>http://web.worldbaseballclassic.com/wbc/2013/video/play.jsp?topic_id=31426364&content_id=24952435&query=game_pk%3D342969</ref>
Israel's third qualifying match was once again against Spain on 23 September 2012. Israel lost this game by a score of 9-7 in 10 innings. With the victory Israel was eliminated from the tournament and Spain moved on to the next round.<ref>http://web.worldbaseballclassic.com/wbc/2013/video/play.jsp?topic_id=31426364&content_id=25045977&query=game_pk%3D342971</ref> Although Israel had won their first two games they were eliminated due to the tournaments [[Double-elimination tournament|modified double-elimination]] format. This meant that the final game was winner-take-all.
===2017 Tournament=== In September 2016, Israel competed in the 2017 [[2017 World Baseball Classic – Qualifier 4|Qualifier 4 round]]. [[Colorado Rockies]] coach [[Jerry Weinstein]] served as the manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forward.com/culture/qa/341319/how-a-survivors-son-is-bringing-baseball-to-israel/|title=How a Survivor's Son Is Bringing Baseball to Israel|publisher=}}</ref> Israel's roster included 20 MLB-affiliated minor leaguers, making up 86% of the team, more than any other team in the qualifiers even before including recent Major Leaguers.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Sports/Israel-off-to-great-start-in-Baseball-Classic-Qualifier-tournament-in-Brooklyn-468522 "Israel off to great start in Baseball Classic Qualifier tournament in Brooklyn" - Israel News<!-- Bot generated title -->], ''Jerusalem Post''</ref>
Israel won all three of their games in the qualifier, beating Great Britain twice<ref name=17game1>{{cite web|url=http://m.mlb.com/gameday/great-britain-vs-israel/2016/09/22/467858?#game_tab=box,game=467858,game_state=final|title=Great Britain vs. Israel - 09/22/16|website=MLB.com}}</ref><ref name=17game3>{{cite web|url=http://m.mlb.com/gameday/great-britain-vs-israel/2016/09/25/467862?#game_tab=box,game=467862,game_state=final|title=Great Britain vs. Israel - 09/25/16|website=MLB.com}}</ref> and Brazil once.<ref name=17game2>{{cite web|url=http://m.mlb.com/gameday/brazil-vs-israel/2016/09/23/467859?#game_tab=box,game=467859,game_state=final|title=Brazil vs. Israel - 09/23/16|website=MLB.com}}</ref> With the win, Israel will play in [[2017 World Baseball Classic – Pool A|Pool A]] in [[South Korea]] in March 2017, against [[South Korea national baseball team|South Korea]], [[Chinese Taipei national baseball team|Taiwan]], and [[Netherlands national baseball team|Netherlands]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/26/sports/baseball/israel-advances-to-the-world-baseball-classic.html|title=Israel Advances to the World Baseball Classic|publisher=|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2016-09-25|last1=Times|first1=The New York}}</ref> In the first round, Israel again swept the round, to advance to the second round in [[2017 World Baseball Classic – Pool E|Pool E]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/18860593/israel-beats-netherlands-4-2-world-baseball-classic|title=Israel handles Dutch to stay unbeaten in WBC|publisher=|date=2017-03-09}}</ref>
==Major League Baseball==
In June 2015 [[Dean Kremer]] became the first Israeli to ever be selected in the Major League Baseball draft, when he was drafted by the [[San Diego Padres]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/sports/.premium-first-israeli-picked-in-mbl-baseball-draft-1.5372973|title=Dean Kremer Becomes First Israeli Citizen Picked in MLB Draft, by San Diego Padres|first=Haaretz Sports|last=Staff|date=18 June 2015|publisher=|via=Haaretz|newspaper=Haaretz}}</ref> It was announced on July 22 that he would honor his commitment and play for the [[UNLV Rebels]], which left three years on his eligibility at the time,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unlvrebels.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/112014aaa.html|title=Rebels Sign Nine For 2015-16 - University of Nevada Las Vegas|website=University of Nevada Las Vegas}}</ref> with the plan of playing professionally after college.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onlysimchas.com/news/12811/first-ever-israeli-dean-kremer-drafted-by-the-san-diego-padres|title=First Ever Israeli Dean Kremer Drafted By The San Diego Padres|publisher=}}</ref> In the [[2016 Major League Baseball draft|2016 Major League Baseball Draft]], Kremer was picked in the 14th round by the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], 431 overall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truebluela.com/2016/6/12/11913930/2016-mlb-draft-dean-kremer-dodgers-14th-round|title=MLB Draft 2016: Dodgers 14th-round pick Dean Kremer was first Israeli drafted in MLB|first=Eric|last=Stephen|work=SB Nation|date=June 12, 2016|accessdate=June 13, 2016}}</ref> His signing was announced by the Dodgers on 16 June<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truebluela.com/2016/6/16/11961872/andre-scrubb-contract-dodgers-2016-mlb-draft|title=Dodgers sign 8th-round pick Andre Scrubb|first=Eric|last=Stephen|work=SB Nation|date=June 16, 2016|accessdate=June 17, 2016}}</ref> and he made his professional debut on 3 July for the [[Ogden Raptors]] of the [[Pioneer Baseball League]].
==Ballparks== Currently there are three main [[ballpark]]s in Israel. *[[Yarkon Sports Complex]], in the [[Baptist]] Village in [[Petach Tikva]], just outside [[Tel Aviv]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.triposo.com/poi/Yarkon_Sports_Complex|title=Yarkon Sports Complex|website=www.triposo.com}}</ref> *[[Gezer Field]], about halfway between [[Jerusalem]] and Tel Aviv.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/23/style/out-there-kibbutz-gezer-king-solomon-s-nines.html|title=OUT THERE: KIBBUTZ GEZER; King Solomon's Nines|first=Joel|last=Greenberg|publisher=|newspaper=The New York Times|date=1992-08-23}}</ref> *[[Sportek Baseball Field]], in Tel Aviv.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jstandard.com/articles/2572/1/Batter-up|title=The Jewish Standard|first=Jewish|last=Standard|website=jstandard.com}}</ref>
In January 2017 the roster of the Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic team traveled to [[Beit Shemesh]] to participate in the ground breaking ceremony for the first ever dedicated baseball field in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/for-these-pro-baseball-players-visiting-israel-is-like-coming-home/|title=For these pro-baseball players, visiting Israel is like coming home|publisher=}}</ref> The field is expected to take approximately 2-3 months to design, and be available for use by the end of 2017.<ref>{{cite interview |last= Alter |first= Jody |interviewer= Nachum Segal |url= [nachumsegal.com] |date= January 9, 2017 |at=(1:50 mark)|work= JM in the AM}}</ref>
