{{DISPLAYTITLE: ''Before Watchmen''}} [[File:WATCHMEN 2012 OZY Cvr.jpg|thumb|''Before Watchmen: Ozymandias'' artwork by [[Jae Lee]]]] '''''Before Watchmen''''' is a series of [[comic books]] published by [[DC Comics]] in 2012. Acting as a [[prequel]] to the 1986 12-issue ''[[Watchmen]]'' [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] by writer [[Alan Moore]] and artist [[Dave Gibbons]], the project consists of eight limited series and one [[One-shot (comics)|one-shot]] (though two were initially planned) for a total of 37 issues.
==Publication history== Moore stated in 1985 that if the ''Watchmen'' limited series was well-received, he and Gibbons would possibly create a 12-issue prequel series called ''Minutemen'' featuring the 1940s superhero group from the story.<ref name="TCJ106">Heintjes, Tom (March 1986). "Alan Moore On (Just About) Everything". ''[[The Comics Journal]]''.</ref> DC offered Moore and Gibbons chances to publish prequels to the series, such as ''Rorschach's Journal'' or ''The Comedian's Vietnam War Diary'', as well as hinting at the possibility of other authors using the same universe. Tales of the Comedian's Vietnam War experiences were floated because ''[[The 'Nam]]'' was popular at the time, while another suggestion was, according to Gibbons, for a "Nite Owl/Rorschach team" (in the manner of ''[[Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)]]'', and also in the sense that the original Charlton characters Blue Beetle and The Question had worked together as a team from time-to-time). Neither man felt the stories would have gone anywhere, with Moore particularly adamant that DC not go forward with stories by other individuals.<ref name="CI65p61">"Watchmen Round Table: Moore & Gibbons". ''[[David Anthony Kraft]]'s [[Comics Interview]]''. Issue 65, 1988.</ref> Gibbons was more attracted to the idea of a ''Minutemen'' series, because it would have "[paid] homage to the simplicity and unsophisticated nature of Golden Age comic books—with the added dramatic interest that it would be a story whose conclusion is already known. It would be, perhaps, interesting to see how we got to the conclusion."<ref name="Comics Bulletin">Young, Thom. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110523081714/http://www.comicsbulletin.com/features/12289382257709.htm Watching the Watchmen with Dave Gibbons: An Interview]". ''[[Comics Bulletin]]''. 2008. Retrieved on December 12, 2008. Archived from the [http://www.comicsbulletin.com/features/12289382257709.htm original] on February 1, 2012.</ref>
In 2010, Moore told ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' that DC offered him the rights to ''Watchmen'' back earlier that week, if he would agree to prequel and sequel projects. Moore said that "if they said that 10 years ago, when I asked them for that, then yeah it might have worked ... But these days I don't want ''Watchmen'' back. Certainly, I don't want it back under those kinds of terms." DC Comics co-publishers [[Dan DiDio]] and [[Jim Lee]] responded, "DC Comics would only revisit these iconic characters if the creative vision of any proposed new stories matched the quality set by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons nearly 25 years ago, and our first discussion on any of this would naturally be with the creators themselves."<ref>Thill, Scott. (July 21, 2010). [https://www.wired.com/underwire/2010/07/alan-moore-watchmen "Alan Moore: 'I Don't Want Watchmen Back'"]. ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved on February 1, 2012.</ref>
Following months of rumors about a potential ''Watchmen'' follow-up project, in February 2012 DC announced seven prequel limited series under the "Before Watchmen" banner: ''Rorschach'', ''Minutemen'', ''Dr. Manhattan'', ''Comedian'', ''Silk Spectre'', ''Nite Owl'', and ''Ozymandias''. The books were written by [[J. Michael Straczynski]], [[Brian Azzarello]], [[Darwyn Cooke]], and [[Len Wein]], and drawn by [[Lee Bermejo]], [[J. G. Jones]], [[Adam Hughes]], [[Andy Kubert]], [[Joe Kubert]], and [[Amanda Conner]]. Every issue featured a two-page installment of the backup series "Curse of the Crimson Corsair" written by Len Wein and drawn by original ''Watchmen'' colorist [[John Higgins (comics)|John Higgins]]. The backup was inspired by the ''Tales of the Black Freighter'' [[story within a story]] from the original ''Watchmen''. A ''Before Watchmen: Epilogue'' one-shot was announced but never published.
Gibbons stated, {{quote|The original series of ''Watchmen'' is the complete story that Alan Moore and I wanted to tell. However, I appreciate DC's reasons for this initiative and the wish of the artists and writers involved to pay tribute to our work. May these new additions have the success they desire.<ref>Phegley, Kiel (February 1, 2012). [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=36724 "DC Comics to Publish 'Before Watchmen' Prequels"]. CBR.com. Retrieved on February 1, 2012.</ref>}}
Moore criticized the project, calling it "completely shameless", and stated he was not interested in monetary compensation, but rather “What I want is for this not to happen.”<ref>Itzkoff, Dave. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/01/books/dc-comics-plans-prequels-to-watchmen-series.html?_r=1 DC Plans Prequels to Watchmen Series]". ''The New York Times''. February 1, 2012. Retrieved on February 1, 2012.</ref> Moore elaborated, {{quote|What the comics industry has effectively said is, 'Yes, this was the only book that made us briefly special and that was because it wasn't like all the other books.' ''Watchmen'' was something that stood on its own and it had the integrity of a literary work. What they've decided now is, 'So, let's change it to a regular comic that can run indefinitely and have spin-offs.' and 'Let's make it as unexceptional as possible.' Like I say, they're doing this because they haven't got any other choices left, evidently.<ref>[http://www.seraphemera.org/seraphemera_books/AlanMoore_Page4.html "Interview with Alan Moore"]. Seraphemera. Retrieved on March 23, 2012.</ref>}}
==Titles==
===''Before Watchmen: Minutemen'' (six issues)=== Writer/Artist: [[Darwyn Cooke]]<ref name=DCPressRelease>[http://www.dccomics.com/tags/jg-jones "DC Entertainment Announces Official Publication Date for BEFORE WATCHMEN"]. [[DC Comics]]. March 12, 2012.</ref>
Hollis Mason, the original [[Nite Owl]], recounts his exploits with [[List of Watchmen characters#Minutemen|The Minutemen]] during the 1940s, while in the midst of his retirement, he faces opposition to the publication of his tell-all autobiography, ''Under the Hood'' in the early 1960s. Although it heavily [[retconned]] certain characters' backstories by suggesting that a large part of ''Under the Hood'' was dirty lies and cover ups, it debuted to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/06/06/before-watchmen-minutemen-1-review |title=Before Watchmen: Minutemen #1 Review |publisher=IGN |date=2012-05-18 |accessdate=2012-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://geek-news.mtv.com/2012/06/06/before-watchmen-minutemen-1-review/ |title=MTV Geek – ‘Before Watchmen: Minutemen #1′ Is The Very Best Modern Comics Have To Offer [Review] |publisher=Geek-news.mtv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-09}}</ref><ref>Brian Salvatore and David Harper (8 June 2012). "[http://multiversitycomics.com/reviews/review-before-watchmen-minutemen-1/ "Review: Before Watchmen: Minutemen #1"]. Multiversity Comics.</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Silk Spectre'' (four issues)=== Writers: Darwyn Cooke and [[Amanda Conner]]. Artist: Amanda Conner<ref name=DCPressRelease/>
The story follows Laurie Jupiter as she rebels against her mother Sally's efforts for Laurie to replace her as the [[List of Watchmen characters#Silk Spectre|Silk Spectre]]. Laurie runs away with her boyfriend to discover herself in the [[San Francisco]] [[counterculture of the 1960s]]. The story debuted to mixed reviews.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mania Entertainment reviews Before Watchmen: Silk Spectre #1|url=http://www.mania.com/silk-spectre-1-comic-review_article_133373.html|publisher=Mania Entertainment|accessdate=28 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223183311/http://www.mania.com/silk-spectre-1-comic-review_article_133373.html|archive-date=2014-12-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=4854 |title=Review: Before Watchmen: Silk Spectre #1 |publisher=Comic Book Resources |date= |accessdate=2012-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/06/13/before-watchmen-silk-spectre-1-review |title=Before Watchmen: Silk Spectre #1 Review |publisher=IGN |date= |accessdate=2012-06-16}}</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Comedian'' (six issues)=== Writer: [[Brian Azzarello]]. Artist: [[J. G. Jones]]<ref name=DCPressRelease/>
The story reveals the [[List of Watchmen characters#The Comedian|Comedian]]'s history with the [[Kennedy family]] during his exploits in the violent [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] Era. It debuted to mostly negative reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/comics/best-shots-extra-avx-6-120620.html |title=Best Shots Extra: Avengers Vs. X-Men, Before Watchmen: Comedian, More |publisher=Newsarama.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://geek-news.mtv.com/2012/06/20/review-before-watchmen-comedian-1/ |title=MTV Geek – Review: ‘Before Watchmen: Comedian’ Is No Killing Joke |publisher=Geek-news.mtv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref><ref name="Mania Entertainment Reviews Before Watchmen: The Comedian #1">{{cite web|title=The Comedian #1 is the best of the Before Watchmen Titles so far|url=http://www.mania.com/comedian-1-comic-review_article_133432.html|publisher=Mania Entertainment|accessdate=28 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150303174642/http://www.mania.com/comedian-1-comic-review_article_133432.html|archive-date=2015-03-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>David Harper and Brian Salvatore, "[http://multiversitycomics.com/reviews/review-before-watchmen-the-comedian-1/ Review: Before Watchmen: The Comedian #1]", www.multiversitycomics.com, 22 June 2012</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Nite Owl'' (four issues)=== Writer: [[J. Michael Straczynski]]. Artists: [[Andy Kubert|Andy]] and [[Joe Kubert]]<ref name=DCPressRelease/>
The plot takes place in the early 1960s, where 15-year-old Daniel Dreiberg is trained by Hollis Mason, the [[Nite Owl]] who led the vigilante team [[List of Watchmen characters#Minutemen|The Minutemen]], as he narrates his first adventures as the second Nite Owl. Dreiberg and Rorschach did not get along, but they started an early partnership when they begin looking at a series of [[prostitute]] murders. Each recalled the abuse their mother suffered when they were children. Nite Owl inadvertently allows seduction into his world of [[vigilantism]], courtesy of the [[dominatrix]] madam The Twilight Lady, while Rorschach turns toward religion, bringing the duo back together to solve the case. The story debuted to mostly positive reviews.<ref name="Mania Entertainment checks out Before Watchmen: Nite Owl #1">{{cite web|title=The venerable Kubert at 85 years of age can definitely teach a thing or two to many modern artists.|url=http://www.mania.com/before-watchmen-nite-owl-1-comic-review_article_133481.html|publisher=Mania Entertainment|accessdate=3 July 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223191136/http://www.mania.com/before-watchmen-nite-owl-1-comic-review_article_133481.html|archive-date=2014-12-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/06/27/before-watchmen-nite-owl-1-review |title=Before Watchmen: Nite Owl #1 Review |publisher=IGN |date= |accessdate=2012-06-28}}</ref><ref>Brian Salvatore and David Harper, "[http://multiversitycomics.com/reviews/review-before-watchmen-nite-owl-1/ Review: Before Watchmen Nite Owl #1]", www.multiversitycomics.com, 29 June 2012</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Ozymandias'' (six issues)=== Writer: [[Len Wein]]. Artist: [[Jae Lee]]<ref name=DCPressRelease/>
As he awaits the final moment for his master plan to come together, [[Ozymandias (comics)|Ozymandias]] reflects on what brought him there and makes an autobiographical recording of his life that spans 1939-1985 (when the story of ''[[Watchmen]]'' takes place). We see his early studies and adventures, the beginnings of his financial empire and his crime-fighting career, and his first unnerving encounters with The Comedian and Doctor Manhattan—the latter of which prompted him to build his [[Antarctic]] fortress of Karnak, aid in resolving the [[Cuban Missile Crisis]], and retire from crime-fighting to concentrate on saving the world at any cost. The story debuted to mostly positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mania Entertainment reviews Ozymandias #1|url=http://www.mania.com/before-watchmen-ozymandias-1-comic-review_article_133541.html|publisher=Mania Entertainment|accessdate=21 August 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150325133734/http://www.mania.com/before-watchmen-ozymandias-1-comic-review_article_133541.html|archive-date=2015-03-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Writer:  Len Wein |url=http://comics.cosmicbooknews.com/content/advanced-review-watchmen-ozymandias-1-6 |title=Advanced Review: Before Watchmen: Ozymandias #1 (of 6) - Cosmic Book News |publisher=Comics.cosmicbooknews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-05}}</ref><ref>Brian Salvatore and David Harper, "[http://multiversitycomics.com/reviews/review-before-watchmen-ozymandias-1/ Review: Before Watchmen: Ozymandias #1]", www.multiversitycomics.com, 6 July 2012</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Rorschach'' (four issues)=== Writer: Brian Azzarello. Artist: [[Lee Bermejo]]<ref name=DCPressRelease/>
The story follows [[Rorschach (comics)|Rorschach]] in New York City, 1977, where his crime-fighting activities cause him to be targeted by a crime lord running drugs and prostitution in the sordid [[Times Square]]. While focused on the gang, Rorschach makes the mistake of allowing another predator to operate unchallenged. The story debuted to mixed reviews.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mania Entertainment Reviews Rorschach #1 |url=http://www.mania.com/before-watchmen-rorschach-1-comic-review_article_133908.html |publisher=Mania Entertainment |accessdate=21 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120822043956/http://www.mania.com/before-watchmen-rorschach-1-comic-review_article_133908.html |archivedate=22 August 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>Brian Salvatore and David Harper, "[http://multiversitycomics.com/reviews/review-before-watchmen-rorschach-1/ Review: Before Watchmen: Rorschach #1]", www.multiversitycomics.com, 17 August 2012</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Thill |first=Scott |url=https://www.wired.com/underwire/2012/08/before-watchmen-rorschach/ |title=Review: Before Watchmen's Rorschach Has Been There, Done That | Underwire |publisher=Wired.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Dr. Manhattan'' (four issues)=== Writer: J. Michael Straczynski. Artist: [[Adam Hughes]]<ref name=DCPressRelease/>
The story explores the [[alternate histories|different universes]] that [[List of Watchmen characters#Doctor Manhattan|Doctor Manhattan]] alias Jon Osterman simultaneously perceives. It also adds a notable new element to Osterman's backstory by revealing him to be a half-[[Jewish]] German immigrant who escaped with his father from the [[Third Reich]] to America; in the original Watchmen series, he was not implied to be anything other than American. It debuted to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/22/before-watchmen-doctor-manhattan-1-review |title=Before Watchmen: Doctor Manhattan #1 Review |publisher=IGN |date= |accessdate=2012-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/57813#1 |title=Ain't It Cool News: The best in movie, TV, DVD, and comic book news |publisher=Aintitcool.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-23}}</ref><ref>Brian Salvatore and David Harper, "[http://multiversitycomics.com/reviews/review-before-watchmen-dr-manhattan-1/ Review: Before Watchmen: Dr. Manhattan #1]", www.multiversitycomics.com, 24 August 2012</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Moloch'' (two issues)=== Writer: J. Michael Straczynski. Artist: [[Eduardo Risso]]<ref name=CBR.ccStory>[http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=40654 "FAN EXPO: JMS & Risso Launch "Before Watchmen: Moloch"][[Comic Book Resources]] Aug 25, 2012</ref>
[[List of Watchmen characters#Adversaries|Moloch]], alias Edgar William Jacobi, was an ex-nemesis of the Minutemen who played a [[macguffin]] role in the original series. This story reveals engrossing information about Moloch's childhood, his turn to villainy, and new details surrounding his death. According to [[review aggregation]] website Comic Book Roundup, the series received an average score of 5.8/10 based on 12 critic reviews.<ref>"[Before Watchmen: Moloch Comic Series Reviews]," Comic Book Roundup. Retrieved August 29, 2016</ref>
===''Before Watchmen: Dollar Bill'' (one-shot)=== Writer: Len Wein. Artist: Steve Rude
The story explores Bill Brady, the corporate-sponsored superhero and Minutemen team member known as Dollar Bill.<ref>{{cite web|last=Webb|first=Charles|title=In January, Len Wein Redeems A Fallen Hero In 'Before Watchmen: Dollar Bill' #1|url=http://geek-news.mtv.com/2012/11/02/len-wein-on-before-watchmen-dollar-bill-in-january/|publisher=MTV Geek|accessdate=2 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407220051/http://geek-news.mtv.com/2012/11/02/len-wein-on-before-watchmen-dollar-bill-in-january/|archive-date=2013-04-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Unpublished=== ====''Before Watchmen: Epilogue'' (one-shot)==== Writers: Various. Artists: Various
The planned ''Epilogue'' one-shot was cancelled.<ref>http://www.bleedingcool.com/2013/04/30/talking-to-len-wein-about-his-career-his-legacy-and-before-watchmen-c2e/</ref> It would have featured a ''Crimson Corsair'' story written by Len Wein and drawn by John Higgins.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hyde|first=David|title=DC Entertainment Officially Announces "Before Watchmen"|url=http://www.dccomics.com/blog/2012/02/01/dc-entertainment-officially-announces-%25e2%2580%259cbefore-watchmen%25e2%2580%259d|publisher=DC Comics|accessdate=3 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69gYoIwk2?url=http://www.dccomics.com/blog/2012/02/01/dc-entertainment-officially-announces-%25e2%2580%259cbefore-watchmen%25e2%2580%259d|archivedate=5 August 2012|df=}}</ref> Higgins had also written and drawn the ''Crimson Corsair'' back-up features that appear in many of the ''Before Watchmen'' publications.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mullin|first=Pamela|title=Artist John Higgins to write The Curse of the Crimson Corsair|url=http://www.dccomics.com/blog/2012/08/06/artist-john-higgins-to-write-the-curse-of-the-crimson-corsair|publisher=DC Comics|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>
==Collected editions== DC has collected ''Before Watchmen'' in four hardcover and softcover collections, grouped by author.
*Darwyn Cooke: ''Before Watchmen: Minutemen/Silk Spectre'' *Brian Azzarello: ''Before Watchmen: Comedian/Rorschach'' *J. Michael Straczynski: ''Before Watchmen: Nite Owl/Dr. Manhattan'' (also includes ''Before Watchmen: Moloch'') *Len Wein: ''Before Watchmen: Ozymandias/Crimson Corsair'' (also includes ''Before Watchmen: Dollar Bill'')

revision.text:
{{ infobox library | native_name = | native_name_lang = | name = | library_logo = | image = Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum logo.png | caption = | country = USA | type = [[Research library]] | scope = [[Comics|Comic art]] | established = 1977 | ref_legal_mandate = | location = [[Columbus, Ohio]] | coordinates = {{coord|39.9996|N|83.009|W|display=inline,title|region:US-OH_type:edu}} | branch_of = [[Ohio State University]] Libraries | num_branches = | items_collected = | collection_size = | criteria = | legal_deposit = | req_to_access = | annual_circulation = | pop_served = | members = | budget = | director = Jenny E. Robb, Curator and Associate Professor
Lucy Caswell, Founder and former Curator
Wendy Pflug, Associate Curator and Assistant Professor
Caitlin McGurk, Associate Curator for Outreach and Assistant Professor | num_employees = | website = [http://cartoons.osu.edu/ cartoons.osu.edu] | phone_num = 614.292.0538 }} The '''Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum''' is a [[research library]] of American [[cartoon]]s and comic art affiliated with the [[Ohio State University]] library system in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. Formerly known as the '''Cartoon Research Library''' and the '''Cartoon Library & Museum''', it holds the world's largest and most comprehensive academic research facility documenting and displaying original and printed [[comic strip]]s, [[editorial cartoon]]s, and cartoon art. The museum is named after the Ohio cartoonist [[Billy Ireland]].[http://cartoons.osu.edu/ Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum][https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6230905 NPR: Cartoon Library & Museum] Covering [[comic book]]s, [[daily strip]]s, [[Sunday strip]]s, [[editorial cartoon]]s, [[graphic novel]]s, magazine [[cartoon]]s, and sports cartoons, the collection includes 450,000 original cartoons, 36,000 books, 51,000 serial titles, and {{convert|3000|ft|m}} of manuscript materials, plus 2.5 million comic strip clippings and tear sheets. == History == [[File:Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum - early newspaper and magazine collections, in the stacks.jpg|thumb|left|Early newspaper and magazine collections]] The Cartoon Library began in 1977 when the [[Milton Caniff|Milton Caniff Collection]] was donated to Ohio State and delivered to the School of Journalism, which was headed by Lucy Shelton Caswell, who became the Milton Caniff Reading Room first curator. Interviewed by Matt Tauber, Caswell detailed the museum's origins and how she became involved: {{cquote|Caniff loved his university very much and truly believed that without the education he got here, he would not have achieved the things that he did. So, his sense of gratitude to the university was palpable... Somebody had to be responsible to make sure it was all there, and all the boxes had my name on it. When funding was made available to work on Caniff, I was offered a six-month appointment. I’ve been here ever since. The original collection was housed in the Journalism building. When I started working with it, we were in two classrooms that had been converted, a door cut between them, so that one was a reading room and one was a storage area... At the time that I started, there weren’t really the kinds of resources to teach and learn about comics that we have now. So, I basically had to make it up as we went along. There just wasn’t anything else out there. As a good librarian and scholar, I started writing around to other places that said they had cartoon collections to see how they did things, because you don’t want to reinvent the wheel if somebody’s already figured it out. It turned out that nobody had the kind of thing that we had in the Caniff collection, i.e. so extensive, and the combination of art and manuscript materials. And nobody else was trying to grow it the way we were.[http://matttauber.blogspot.com/2009/01/lucy-shelton-caswell-interview-part-1.html Tauber, Matt. "Lucy Shelton Caswell Interview - part 1", January 30, 2009.]}} From two classrooms off the back hallway of the Journalism Building in 1977, the collection expanded to three classrooms and became part of the University Libraries. By 1989, the three classrooms were filled, and the library moved into a larger space, eventually requiring the use of off-site storage as the collection continued to expand. (At that point, the facility was named the Cartoon Research Library.) In 1992, [[United Media]] donated the Robert Roy Metz Collection of 83,034 original cartoons by 113 cartoonists. In 1998, the San Francisco Academy of Comic Art Collection was acquired from its director, [[Bill Blackbeard]], giving the library the largest collection of newspaper comic-strip tear sheets and clippings in the world. Six semitrailer trucks transported this collection from California to Ohio. In 2007, [[King Features Syndicate]] donated its [[Comic strip#Newspapers|proof-sheet]] collection, consisting of over two million strips (a duplicate set was donated to [[Michigan State University Libraries#Comic Art Collection|Michigan State University's Comic Art Collection]]).Randy Scott. "The King Features Proof Sheet Collection." ''Insight''. [Fall 2009?] p.3 In June 2008, the collection of the [[National Cartoon Museum|International Museum of Cartoon Art]] (more than 200,000 originals with an estimated value of $20 million) was transferred to the Cartoon Library & Museum. Founded in 1973 by cartoonist [[Mort Walker]], the IMCA collection includes a wide variety of original cartoon art (comic strips, comic books, animation, editorial, advertising, sport, caricature, greeting cards, graphic novels, and illustrations), display figures, toys, and collectibles, plus works on film and tape, CDs, and DVDs.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121615221992855615 |title=Beetle Bailey's Long March: Classic Cartoons Search for a Home |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' |author=Mary Pilon |authorlink=Mary Pilon |date=July 16, 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-06}}[http://www.boston.com/news/local/connecticut/articles/2008/05/16/addition_to_make_schools_comic_art_collection_really_super/ Whiteman, Doug. "Addition to make school's comic art collection really super", Associated Press, May 16, 2008.] The 2009 exhibition ''From Yellow Kid to Conan: American Cartoons from the International Museum of Cartoon Art Collection'' was held at the Cartoon Library and Museum from June to August. In September 2009, it was announced that the Ohio State University Board of Trustees approved a new name, Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum, in recognition of a $7 million gift from an anonymous donor to support the renovation of Sullivant Hall. The museum was named in honor of [[William Addison Ireland]] (1880 – May 29, 1935), a self-taught cartoonist (and native of [[Chillicothe, Ohio]]) well known throughout Ohio as Billy Ireland. A native of Chillicothe, Ohio, Billy Ireland was a self-taught cartoonist who was hired by ''The Columbus Dispatch'' shortly after his 1898 high school graduation. Until his death, Ireland worked in Columbus for the ''Dispatch'', drawing both editorial cartoons and his Sunday feature, ''The Passing Show''. His work was exhibited by the museum in 2003. === Former names === * Milton Caniff Reading Room, 1977 * Library for Communication and Graphic Arts * Cartoon, Graphic, and Photographic Arts Research Library * Cartoon Research Library, 1989 * Cartoon Library and Museum, July 2009 * Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum, September 2009 == Collections and archives == [[File:Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum - inside an aisle of compact shelving.jpg|thumb|An aisle of stored comics]] The Milton Caniff Collection consists of 12,000 original artworks by Caniff, 85 boxes of memorabilia, and more than 450 boxes of manuscript materials, fan letters, and business records. As the museum's collection of original art and manuscripts evolved and expanded, it added the [[Nick Anderson (cartoonist)|Nick Anderson]] Collection, the [[Jim Borgman]] Collection, the [[Eldon Dedini]] Collection, the [[Edwina Dumm]] Collection, the [[Woody Gelman]] Collection of [[Winsor McCay]] cartoons, the [[Walt Kelly]] Collection, the collection of agent [[Toni Mendez]], and the [[Bill Watterson]] Collection. The [[Bud Blake]] Collection includes more than 5,800 of the cartoon panels he drew for [[King Features Syndicate]] from 1954 to 1965, plus 10,000 daily and Sunday ''[[Tiger (comic strip)|Tiger]]'' originals. Comic-book collections include the [[Will Eisner]] Collection; the [[Jay Kennedy]] Collection has more than 9,500 underground comic books. The museum's collection includes work by [[Anne Mergen]], who was the only female editorial cartoonist in the United States for much of her career.[http://library.osu.edu/blogs/librarynews/2008/01/29/anne-mergen-editorial-cartoonist/ Anne Mergen] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511203241/http://library.osu.edu/blogs/librarynews/2008/01/29/anne-mergen-editorial-cartoonist/ |date=May 11, 2008 }} Library News Ohio State University Archival professional records include the Association of American Editorial Cartoonists, [[National Cartoonists Society]], Newspaper Features Council, and the Cartoonists Guild. A biographical registry of cartoonists contains files for more than 5,000 cartoonists and clipping files organized by cartoon-related subjects. ==Exhibitions== The library sponsors programs related to cartoon art by staging exhibitions, lending for exhibits elsewhere, and hosting speakers, seminars, workshops and conferences. Some physical exhibitions have been made available as digital exhibitions. The Festival of Cartoon Art has been held triennially since 1983. Featuring two days of lectures, panel discussions, exhibitions, and receptions, it attracts cartoonists, comics scholars, fans, collectors, and students. Leading cartoonists have spoken at the festival, including [[Lynda Barry]], [[Milton Caniff]], [[Will Eisner]], [[Jules Feiffer]], [[Ben Katchor]], [[Patrick Oliphant]], [[Jeff Smith (cartoonist)|Jeff Smith]], [[Art Spiegelman]], [[Garry Trudeau]], and [[Bill Watterson]]. == Curators and Staff == [[File:Billy Ireland Cartoon Library Archive Hallway.jpg|left|thumb|Storage space of the museum]] Caswell remained as curator from 1977–2010. She is author of several books on cartooning, including ''Illusions: Ethnicity in American Cartoon Art'' (Ohio State Libraries, 1992) and ''[[Arnold Roth|Arnold Roth: Free Lance]]'' (Fantagraphics, 2001). Jenny E. Robb became the museum's new curator on January 1, 2011, following the December 31, 2010, retirement of Caswell, who returned as curator of special projects in March 2011.[http://dailycartoonist.com/index.php/2010/11/12/lucy-shelton-caswell-retires-from-cartoon-library/ Gardner, Alan. "Lucy Shelton Caswell Retires from Cartoon Library", The Daily Cartoonist, November 12, 2010. ] Before arriving at Ohio State in 2005, Robb was curator of the [[Cartoon Art Museum]] in San Francisco for five years. She has master's degrees in history and museum studies from Syracuse University. Wendy Pflug joined the staff as associate curator in December 2011. Associate Curator and Assistant Professor Caitlin McGurk,{{cite web |last1=Thompson |first1=Erica |title=People to Watch: Caitlin McGurk |url=http://www.columbusalive.com/content/stories/2016/08/04/people-to-watch-caitlin-mcgurk.html |website=Columbus Alive |accessdate=29 June 2018 |date=3 August 2016}} who started as a Visiting Curator in February 2012, manages the libraries outreach efforts, including instruction, exhibits, tours, and social media.{{cite web |last1=Brogan |first1=Jacob |title=How Does a Comic Book Librarian Work? |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/podcasts/working/2017/10/how_does_comic_book_librarian_caitlin_mcgurk_of_the_billy_ireland_cartoon.html |website=Slate.com |accessdate=29 June 2018 |date=22 October 2017}} Other staffers include Assistant Curators Susan Liberator and Marilyn Scott.[http://library.osu.edu/blogs/cartoons/2012/03/22/womens-history-month-who-runs-the-cartoon-library/ "Who Runs the Cartoon Library?"] ==Books and publications== In May 2010, the Ohio State University Press announced Studies in Comics and Cartoons, a series of books edited by Caswell and Jared Gardner, associate professor in the Department of English. Books published in this series will focus on comics and graphic literature with monographs and edited collections covering the history of comics and cartoons from the editorial cartoon and early sequential comics of the 19th century through contemporary international comics and online comics. In 2017, the Ohio State University Press began publishing ''Inks'', a new journal for the Comics Studies Society.{{cite web |title=INKS: The Journal of The Comics Studies Society |url=http://inks.comicssociety.org/ |accessdate=29 June 2018}} This journal is published triannually, and "features scholarly research on sequential art, graphic narrative, and cartooning.{{cite web |title=Inks: The Journal of the Comics Studies Society |url=https://ohiostatepress.org/Inks.html |website=The Ohio State University Press |publisher=The Ohio State University Press |accessdate=29 June 2018}} ==Sullivant Hall Location== Expansion for the Billy Ireland Cartoon Library and Museum included the renovation of historic Sullivant Hall located on High Street adjacent to the [[Wexner Center for the Arts]]. The facility increased the library’s space from {{convert|6808|sqft|m2}} to more than {{convert|40000|sqft|m2}}. It features a reading room for researchers, three museum-quality galleries, and expanded storage space with state-of-the-art environmental and security controls. In May 2009, Jean Schulz, widow of [[Charles M. Schulz]], made a donation of $1 million with a promise of a matching grant if more funds were raised for the renovations. Her challenge was that she would provide an additional gift of $2.5 million if Ohio State raised the same amount from other sources to reach a $6 million total. Cartoonist [[Bil Keane]] and his family answered the Schulz Challenge with a $50,000 gift. The $20.6 million project was completed in 2013,{{cite web |last1=McGirk |first1=Caitlin |title=...And we're back! |url=https://library.osu.edu/blogs/cartoons/2013/09/11/and-were-back/ |website=Billy Ireland Cartoon Library and Museum Blog |accessdate=13 August 2018 |date=11 September 2013}} with Sullivant Hall housing both the Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum and Ohio State's Department of Dance. [[File:Billy Ireland Cartoon Library and Museum lobby.jpg|thumb|Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum lobby]] ==Awards== * In 2011, Lucy Caswell was honored with the Silver T-Square Award from the [[National Cartoonists Society]]. ==Online gallery== Select collections have been digitized and are available as part of the library's Digital Exhibits collection.{{cite web|title=Digital Exhibits|url=http://cartoons.osu.edu/digital-exhibits/|website=Billy Ireland Cartoon Library and Museum|accessdate=2 February 2018}} ==See also== * [[Allan Holtz]] * [[Belgian Centre for Comic Strip Art]] * [[The Cartoon Museum]], London museum dedicated to British cartoons * [[Fred Waring#Comic strip collection|Fred Waring Cartoon Collection]] * [[George Kelley Paperback and Pulp Fiction Collection]] * [[List of newspaper comic strips]] * [[Michigan State University Libraries#Comic Art Collection|Michigan State University Comic Art Collection]] * [[Roger Price (comedy)#Roger Price Gallery|Roger Price Gallery]] * [[ToonSeum]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://library.osu.edu/blogs/cartoons/ Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum Blog] * [http://cartoons.osu.edu/ Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum official site] * [http://potrzebie.blogspot.com/2010/01/death-of-newspapers-11-vault-of-caswell.html Lucy Caswell's video guided tour of the Museum collection] * [http://www.libraryofamericancomics.com/blog/article/2175/ Bruce Canwell visits the Museum] * [http://www.lurid.com/archives/62 Video: P. Craig Russell at the Museum] * [http://osucartoons.pastperfectonline.com/ Explore the Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum Art Database] * [http://cartoons.osu.edu/?q=content/topic-files Cartoon Topic Files] * [https://lib.msu.edu/comics/ Michigan State University Comic Art Collection] * [http://ead.ohiolink.edu/xtf-ead/view?docId=ead/xOhCoUCR0001.xml;chunk.id=a23;brand=default/ San Francisco Academy of Comic Art collection: Comic features, 1894-1996] * [http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/ead/subj_list_from_db.htm#cart Syracuse University Library Special Collections: Cartoonists] {{Comics}} {{Ohio State University|facilities}} {{King Features Syndicate Comics}} {{Columbus, Ohio}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Billy Ireland Cartoon Library and Museum}} [[Category:1977 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1977]] [[Category:Art museums in Ohio]] [[Category:Cartooning museums]] [[Category:Comics-related organizations]] [[Category:Libraries established in 1977]] [[Category:Libraries in Ohio]] [[Category:Media museums in the United States]] [[Category:Museums in Columbus, Ohio]] [[Category:Ohio State University]] [[Category:University museums in Ohio]] [[Category:University District, Columbus, Ohio]]

{{Infobox musical artist | | name = Bob Roberts | image = Ragtime_Bob_Roberts_improved_portrait.jpg | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Robert A. Roberts | alias = "Ragtime" Bob Roberts
Robert Roberts | birth_date = {{birth date|1879|4|27}} |birth_place =[[Cincinnati, Ohio]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1930|1|21|1879|4|27}} |death_place =Cincinnati, Ohio, US | origin = | instrument = [[Vocal]] | genre = [[Novelty song|Novelty]], [[vaudeville]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 1902–c.1920 | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Edison Records|Edison]], [[Victor Records|Victor]], [[Indestructible Records|Indestructible]], others | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Robert A. Roberts''' (April 27, 1879 – January 21, 1930),{{#tag:ref|Reliable sources including Gracyk and Sutton give his middle initial as A., and his year of birth as 1879. However, the 1900 US Census[http://search.ancestry.co.uk/cgi-bin/sse.dll?db=1900usfedcen&indiv=try&h=40186109 1900 US Census, Cincinnati, Robert S. Roberts] records him as Robert S. Roberts, with a birth year of 1871. Cemetery records give his middle initial as S., but his birth year as 1879.|group="note"}} sometimes referred to as '''"Ragtime" Bob Roberts''', was an American [[Novelty song|novelty]] singer in the early years of the 20th century. ==Biography== He was born in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], the son of Nicholas (Nick) Roberts, a well-known [[clown]] who became the proprietor of one of the country's leading touring [[pantomime]] companies. Bob Roberts is assumed to have traveled widely with his father's shows in his youth. He made his recording debut for [[Columbia Records]] in 1902, and initially recorded remakes of other artists' records before starting to make recordings of new songs.[http://www.mainspringpress.com/bobroberts.html Allan Sutton, ''American Recording Pioneers - Bob Roberts]. Retrieved 16 May 2013 Among the most successful of his early recordings for Columbia were "Hurrah For Baffin's Bay" and "By The Sycamore Tree", both in 1903.{{cite book| last1 = Whitburn | first1 = Joel| title = Pop Memories 1890-1954: The History of American Popular Music| location = Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin| publisher = Record Research, Inc. | year= 1986| pages = 371| isbn = 0-89820-083-0}} Roberts also recorded for [[Edison Records|Edison]], [[Victor Records|Victor]], and other companies. He recorded prolifically, recording some songs for several different labels. One of his biggest comedy successes was with "The Woodchuck Song", written by [[Theodore Morse]], with a chorus of "How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?",[http://www.gracyk.com/bobroberts.shtml Tim Gracyk, ''Bob Roberts - Tenor'']. Retrieved 16 May 2013 which he recorded in 1904 for Edison, Columbia, Victor, and [[Zon-O-Phone Records]]. He also recorded for both Edison and Columbia as part of a duo with [[Albert Campbell (singer)|Albert Campbell]]. He was at the peak of his recording career between 1903 and 1907, when he rivaled [[Billy Murray (singer)|Billy Murray]] for popularity, and received a similar payment of $30 for each recording. He and Murray occasionally recorded together, as on "Oh! Oh! Sallie", in 1905. Roberts was a leading exponent of the comedic "[[coon song]]", such as "Wouldn't It Make You Hungry", written by [[Harry Von Tilzer]], and "I'm Satisfied", many of them recorded for Zon-o-phone, a subsidiary of Victor. The number of his recordings started to diminish around 1908, perhaps because he devoted more of his time to stage performances. Roberts spent long periods touring in [[vaudeville]], where he became a popular [[monologist]], and was a leading attraction at the Regal Theater in [[Los Angeles]]. However, he also continued to record for Edison, Columbia, Victor, and other labels such as [[Indestructible Records|Indestructible]]. He had further popular success in 1911 with his recording of "Woodman, Woodman, Spare That Tree", from the ''[[Ziegfeld Follies|Ziegfeld Follies of 1911]]'', and in 1912 with the earliest recording of "[[Ragtime Cowboy Joe]]", for Victor Records. He did not record for any of the major companies after 1913 but, between 1914 and 1917, recorded for the Rex Talking Machine Company as Robert Roberts, including a duet with fellow vaudevillian [[Elida Morris]]. By the 1920s, Roberts had given up touring and returned to live in Cincinnati. According to [[Jim Walsh (columnist)|Jim Walsh]], he ran a [[pool hall]] there, and in the late 1920s appeared on radio station [[WCKY (AM)|WCKY]] in a show called "Adolph and Otto". He died in 1930. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roberts (singer), Bob}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1930 deaths]] [[Category:Musicians from Cincinnati]] [[Category:Victor Records artists]] [[Category:Pioneer recording artists]] [[Category:Columbia Records artists]] [[Category:Zonophone Records artists]] [[Category:Edison Records artists]]

{{Infobox video game| |image=Calripkenjrsnes.jpg |caption=North American cover art |developer=[[Krome Studios Melbourne|Beam Software]] (SNES)
[[ACME Interactive]] (Genesis) |publisher=[[Mindscape]] |release={{vgrelease|NA|December 1992|EU|1993}} |genre=[[Sports game|Sports]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms=[[Sega Genesis]], [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Nintendo]] }} '''Cal Ripken Jr. Baseball''' is a 1992 [[sports game|sports]] video game released in 1992 by [[Mindscape]] for the [[Sega Genesis]] and [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]].http://www.gamefaqs.com/snes/588238-cal-ripken-jr-baseball ==Gameplay== Due to a lack of [[license|licensing]] from [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB), the game features no MLB team names, stadiums, or artwork, and [[Cal Ripken, Jr.]] himself is the only non-fictitious player in the game.{{cn|date=April 2016}} The graphics and sound of the SNES version were seen as a "step up" from its [[Sega Genesis]] counterpart. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1992 video games]] [[Category:Baseball video games]] [[Category:Sega Genesis games]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of American people|Ripken]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of sportspeople|Ripken]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of men|Ripken]] [[Category:Video games based on real people]] {{baseball-videogame-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Orphan|date=March 2013}}
'''Chinese comedy''' has a long history that dates back to the [[Zhou Dynasty]] (1100 BC to 221 BC) when the aristocracy kept jesters in their homes.<ref name="AA">{{Cite news | last = | first = | publication-date = 12 August 2010 | title = Zhou Libo, More than a Stand-up Comedian - Culture China. | periodical = News - Cultural China. | url = http://news.cultural-china.com/20090610112412.html?PHPSESSID=0abcfb166fec607eba491596f30d4bcc | accessdate = 14 August 2010 | postscript =<!--None--> }}</ref> At that time people in higher society were profoundly influenced by the teachings of [[Confucius]]. Therefore, comic shows were usually looked down upon in feudal China. During the late [[Qing Dynasty]] (1644–1911)<ref name = "AA" /> and Republic of China period, different styles of comedy flourished in big cities and the genre of [[xiangsheng]], comic drama began to emerge. Since the 1980s, with the rapid development of media throughout the country, different kinds of comedy have arisen. They became the favorite form of entertainment for the populace. Currently, the most popular genres of Chinese comedy are Chinese skit and [[Xiangsheng]].
==xiangsheng== {{main|xiangsheng (comedy)}} '''Xiangsheng''' ({{zh|t=[[wikt:相聲|相聲]]|s=[[wikt:相声|相声]]|p=xiàngsheng|l=face and voice}}), also known as crosstalk, is a traditional Chinese comedic performance in different forms of dialogue. Xiangsheng is a language art combining four basic techniques: speaking, imitating, teasing, and singing. It can be conducted by one or two performers. It is one of the most popular forms of entertainment because its language is rich in puns and allusions.<ref name ="A">{{Cite news | last = | first = | publication-date = | title = Dashan: Xiangsheng | periodical = Dashan | url = http://www.dashan.com/en/projects/xiangsheng.htm | accessdate = 12 August 2010 | postscript =<!--None--> }}</ref> New developments have been applied to this traditional art in order to keep pace with the times. Xiangsheng is a very contemporary performance. Comedians place emphasis on creating new works and injecting new elements into traditional works making them more relevant to current affairs. It is performed in the form of a [[dialogue]] between two performers, or, much less often, a solo [[monologue]] or, even less frequently, a multi-person dialogue.
==Chinese skit== '''Chinese [[Sketch comedy|skit]]''' is a form of performance about small things in people's daily lives. Chinese skit is generally regarded as originating in 1980s. It has inherited qualities, and developed from other forms of comedy, such as stage play, xiangsheng, [[Er ren zhuan|errenzhuan]] and comic drama. A skit revolves around just one topic, but with a lot of action and lively language. Through promotion by the [[CCTV New Year's Gala|Spring Festival Gala Evening]] over 20 years, Chinese skit became a very popular artistic form in China. The first skit in China was “eating noodles” (in 1984) which was performed by [[Chen Peisi]].
==Shanghai style stand-up comedy== The typical form of Shanghai-style stand-up comedy is the style known as "Shanghai Qing Kou", which was created by [[Zhou Libo (comedian)|Zhou Libo]] — a most famous stand-up comedian in China. "Shanghai Qing Kou" originated from different forms of local stand-up comedy in Shanghai, Beijing and Hong Kong. It is a style of comedy in which the performer speaks directly to the audience on socially popular topics. In the performances the performer will include his or her personal experiences.

{{Infobox stage production | name = Commedus Interruptus | image = Commedus Interruptus Logo.jpg | image_size = | alt = 2012 Commedus Interruptus Logo | caption = | company = [[University of Southern California]] | genre = | type = [[improvisational theatre|Improvisational]] and [[sketch comedy|sketch]] comedy | premiere = <!-- {{Start date|1989|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | finalshow = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = [[Los Angeles, California]] | creatortitle1 = | creatorname1 = | creatortitle2 = | creatorname2 = | creatortitle3 = | creatorname3 = | creatortitle4 = | creatorname4 = | creatortitle5 = | creatorname5 = | creatortitle6 = | creatorname6 = | creatortitle7 = | creatorname7 = | creatortitle8 = | creatorname8 = | creatortitle9 = | creatorname9 = | creatortitle10 = | creatorname10 = | creatortitle11 = | creatorname11 = | creatortitle12 = | creatorname12 = | creatortitle13 = | creatorname13 = | creatortitle14 = | creatorname14 = | creatortitle15 = | creatorname15 = | otherlabel1 = | otherdata1 = | otherlabel2 = | otherdata2 = | otherlabel3 = | otherdata3 = | otherlabel4 = | otherdata4 = | otherlabel5 = | otherdata5 = | website = www.commedus.com }}
'''Commedus Interruptus''' is an American theater troupe operating from the US state of California.
==Origin== Commedus Interruptus originated as a short and long-form [[improvisational theatre]] troupe at the [[University of Southern California]]. The oldest of USC's five currently performing improv troupes, Commedus was created in 1989 by then-senior [[Don Friesen]]. The group is best known for performing a free hour-long lawn show every Friday at 1 p.m. in front of [[Tommy Trojan]]. In addition to their weekly shows, the troupe writes and produces a full-length [[sketch comedy]] show every semester.
Commedus quickly established itself as a fixture within the USC theater community, and has served as a stepping-stone in the careers of many USC alumni.
==Sketch show== Twice a year, Commedus puts on an original [[sketch comedy]] show for the student body, shortly before [[Final examination|finals]] week, showcasing original material written and performed by the Commedus cast (commonly known as the "Commedes"). The show is widely acclaimed by the USC theater community, and performances are regularly sold out. Commedus is currently in the process of filming sketches, which will be released on the troupe's [http://www.justinbettman.com/commedus/?page_id=38 website]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}.
==Annual Improv-a-thon== Every [[Spring (season)|spring]], Commedus performs 24 straight hours of improv as a [[fundraiser]]. The event begins at 2 p.m. Thursday and ends with Commedus' regular lawn show, from 1-2 p.m. Friday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailytrojan.com/2012/03/22/long-running-joke/ |title=Long-running joke |publisher=Daily Trojan |date=2012-03-22 |accessdate=2016-07-08}}</ref> The event has become a staple of the Commedus calendar, and is well-attended throughout its twenty-four-hour span.
==Audition process== Commedus Interruptus holds auditions each [[Fall]], open to [[undergraduates]] of all [[Academic major|majors]]. The primary [[audition]]s are administered jointly with three other USC improv troupes: [[Second Nature Improv|Second Nature]], The Merry Men, and Spoiler Alert, after which each troupe will offer callbacks on an individual basis. Commedus is unique, however, in that it requires an additional workshop phase: eight candidates are selected to be mentored by the troupe over a six-week period, after which 1-4 will be invited onto the troupe proper. This unusual process is designed to assess the candidates' ability to display talent consistently, take direction and improve over time, and work collaboratively with the rest of the group.
==Current cast== *Antonio Chicco *Haley Spence Brown *Jack "Cinco" DeMeo *Catie Ryan *Tatiana Aarons *Jay "Smackdown" Kane *Sam Pirie *Jacob Surovsky *Matthew Kerr *Tommy Derken *Julia Wisnia *Leo Driessen
==Alumni== *[[Don Friesen]], [[stand-up comedian]] and two-time winner of the [[San Francisco International Comedy Competition]] *[[Jason Reitman]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Wheeler |first=John |url=http://dailytrojan.com/2009/12/01/reitman-finds-himself-on-the-ascent/ |title=Reitman finds himself on the ascent |publisher=Daily Trojan |date=2009-12-01 |accessdate=2016-07-08}}</ref> [[Academy Award]]-nominated director of [[Juno (film)|Juno]] and [[Up in the Air (2009 film)|Up in the Air]] *Abby Kohn,<ref>[https://archive.is/20130204223801/http://www.trustfallcomedy.com/about.html ]</ref> writer of [[Never Been Kissed]] and [[Valentine's Day (2010 film)|Valentine's Day]] *Damien Haas, former cast member of [[So Random!]], a [[Disney Channel]] sketch comedy series and current cast member of [[Smosh]] *[[Beck Bennett]],<ref name="DT GN">{{cite web|last=Violette |first=James |url=http://dailytrojan.com/2011/01/23/student-comedy-group-grabs-attention/ |title=Student comedy group grabs attention |publisher=Daily Trojan |date=2011-01-23 |accessdate=2016-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Kevin Fallon |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/04/09/beck-bennett-meet-that-guy-in-those-adorable-at-t-commercials.html |title=Beck Bennett: Meet That Guy in Those Adorable AT&T Commercials |publisher=The Daily Beast |date= |accessdate=2016-07-08}}</ref> star of the [[AT&T Mobility|AT&T]] "It's Not Complicated" commercials and [[Saturday Night Live]] cast member<ref name="GN SNL">{{cite web|url=http://thecomicscomic.com/2014/09/09/snl-hires-nick-rutherford-to-reunite-write-with-his-good-neighbor-mates/ |title=SNL hires Nick Rutherford to reunite, write with his Good Neighbor mates | The Comic's Comic |website=Thecomicscomic.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-08}}</ref> *[[Kyle Mooney]], cast member of [[Saturday Night Live]]<ref name="GN SNL" /> *[[Nick Rutherford]], writer for [[Saturday Night Live]]<ref name="GN SNL" /> Additionally, the following comedy groups have been formed by alumni of the Commedus cast: *Good Neighbor<ref name="DT GN"/> *Trust Fall *Invisible Engine *Summer of Tears
==''Saturday Night Live''== In 2013, Commedus Interruptus Alumni [[Beck Bennett]] and [[Kyle Mooney]] were made featured players on the legendary New York-based sketch comedy show, ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. [[Nick Rutherford]] joined the show as a writer in 2014.<ref name="GN SNL"/>

The '''Congaroos''' (also known as '''Four Congaroos''', '''Congaroo Dancers''') was a dance group created in 1947 by [[Frankie Manning]] after completing his military service for [[World War II]].<ref> {{cite book | last = Manning | first = Frankie | authorlink = Frankie Manning |author2=Cynthia R. Millman | title = Frankie Manning: Ambassador of Lindy Hop | year = 2007 | publisher = Temple University Press | location = Philadelphia, Pennsylvania | isbn = 1-59213-563-3 | pages = 204–208, 212–216, 243, 253 }} </ref> The group originally consisted of Frankie Manning dancing with Ann Johnson and Russell Williams dancing with Willamae Ricker. Later Helen Daniels joined the group and partnered Frankie Manning. The group performed [[Lindy Hop]], [[Conga (dance)|Conga]], [[jazz dance]], [[tap dance]], [[Latin dance]]s, and comedy with musicians and vocalists such as [[Alvino Rey]], [[Lucky Millinder]], [[Illinois Jacquet]], [[Ella Fitzgerald]], [[Count Basie]], [[Erskine Hawkins]], [[Andy Kirk (musician)|Andy Kirk]], [[Fletcher Henderson]], and [[Cab Calloway]].
The group disbanded in 1955. For their final performance at a benefit in [[Philadelphia]], [[Lionel Hampton]] refused to play the music for their act. Consequently, the Congaroos did not get a chance to rehearse and were forced to improvise their entire act to music that Lionel Hampton chose.
== Filmography ==
* ''[[Killer Diller (1948 film)|Killer Diller]]'' (1948) * Killer Diller 1948 * [https://archive.org/details/killer_diller See, download Killer Diller at Internet Archive] Congaroos begin @ ~ 51:20

{{italic title}} '''''Country''''' was the first book published by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine critic [[Nick Tosches]]. Released in 1977 under the title '''''Country: The Biggest Music in America''''', it was retitled in later editions as '''''Country: Living Legends and Dying Metaphors in America's Biggest Music''''' and '''''Country: The Twisted Roots of Rock and Roll'''''.
Rather than a detailed, chronological study of country music, the book is arranged like a fan's scrapbook, leaping across time and subject. Throughout ''Country'', Tosches makes a point of paying tribute to pivotal but undersung figures in country, hillbilly, and blues music, including [[Emmett Miller]], [[Cliff Carlisle]], and [[Val and Pete]].<ref>[http://www.puremusic.com/tosches.html Review of Country: The Twisted Roots of Rock 'n' Roll from Puremusic.com]</ref> He also pays tribute to early music writers, such as [[Emma Bell Miles]], whose 1904 essay "Some Real American Music" Tosches called "the most beautiful prose written of country music."<ref>[http://heyrobertsilva.com/blog/2010/08/30/some-real-american-music-reexamined/ Some Real American Music -- Reexamined]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1977 books]] [[Category:Music books]] [[Category:Books by Nick Tosches]]

{{about| the 2007 horror film|the Billy Talent album|Dead Silence (album)|the 1997 film of the same name starring James Garner|Dead Silence (1997 film)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Dead Silence | image = Dead silence.jpg | image_size = 220px | border = yes | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[James Wan]] | producer = [[Mark Burg]]
[[Oren Koules]]
[[Gregg Hoffman]] | screenplay = [[Leigh Whannell]] | story = James Wan
Leigh Whannell | starring = [[Ryan Kwanten]]
[[Amber Valletta]]
[[Donnie Wahlberg]]
[[Michael Fairman]]
Joan Heney
[[Bob Gunton]]
[[Judith Roberts (actress)|Judith Roberts]]
[[Laura Regan]] | music = [[Charlie Clouser]] | cinematography = [[John R. Leonetti]] | editing = Michael Knue | studio = [[Twisted Pictures]] | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2007|03|16}} | runtime = 89 minutes
92 minutes {{small|(Unrated cut)}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $20 million{{mojo title|deadsilence|Dead Silence}} | gross = $22.2 million }} '''''Dead Silence''''' is a 2007 American [[Supernatural fiction|supernatural]] [[horror film]] directed by [[James Wan]] and written by [[Leigh Whannell]], the creators of ''[[Saw (franchise)|Saw]]''. The film stars [[Ryan Kwanten]], [[Judith Roberts (actress)|Judith Roberts]], [[Donnie Wahlberg]], and [[Amber Valletta]].{{cite web|title=The Top 10 Killer Toy Movies for the Holidays!|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/editorials/18495/the-top-10-killer-toy-movies-for-the-holidays/|work=Bloody Disgusting|publisher=BLOODY DISGUSTING LLC|accessdate=1 August 2012|author=Chris Eggertsen|date=23 December 2009}} While the movie did receive negative reviews at its release, it has since gathered a cult following. ==Plot== Jamie Ashen and his wife, Lisa, receive an anonymous gift of a [[ventriloquist]] doll called "Billy". While Lisa is playing with Billy, a figure approaches her, causing her to scream. Jamie finds her dead with her tongue cut out. After Jamie is released from custody by Detective Jim Lipton due to lack of evidence, he spots inside Billy's box a mysterious message about "Mary Shaw", a deceased ventriloquist from his hometown, Raven's Fair. At Raven's Fair, Jamie visits his estranged and wealthy father, Edward (who uses a wheelchair), and his much-younger wife, Ella, for information regarding Mary Shaw. Dismissing them as superstitions, Jamie arranges for Lisa's funeral with the help of a local mortician, Henry Walker. Jamie meets Henry's senile wife, Marion, who tells him of the danger of Mary and her puppet, Billy. After burying Billy, Jamie is confronted by Detective Lipton in his motel room, the latter still doubting Jamie, and digs up Billy, after Jamie leaves the cemetery where Mary Shaw and the rest of her dummies are buried. Henry tells Jamie that Mary Shaw was a famous ventriloquist who was publicly humiliated when a young boy named Michael rudely claimed that he could see her lips moving during one of her performances. Michael disappeared some weeks later, and his family blamed it on Shaw and lynched her. Mary's last wish was to have her body turned into a dummy and buried with her 101 dolls. Henry, then the young son of the local mortician, saw Shaw (after she was turned to a dummy) rise up, but Henry was spared thanks to his having kept his mouth shut. This is because Shaw takes her revenge by killing only those who scream. Jamie finds out that Michael, the first victim, was his great uncle; the Ashen family were the ones who killed Shaw by cutting out her tongue, and she has been seeking revenge against their entire bloodline by killing them in the same way. While crawling under the house after discovering Marion with the Billy puppet, Henry is killed by Shaw, who steals his tongue. Detective Lipton discovers that all of Shaw's dolls have been dug up. He informs Jamie, who receives a call from "Henry," asking him to go to Shaw's theatre. There, both Jamie and Detective Lipton discover 100 of the dolls lined up with Michael's body, which has been turned into a marionette. Through a clown doll, Shaw reveals to Jamie that she killed his wife because she was pregnant with his son, thus killing any potential newborn of the Ashen family. Jamie and Lipton burn the theatre and all of Shaw's dolls, though in the process, Shaw successfully makes Detective Lipton scream and kills him. Back at his father's residence, Jamie is confronted by Mary Shaw, but he repels her by throwing Billy (the 101st and last of the remaining dummies) into the fireplace. He is horrified to learn that his father had already died long ago; the current "Edward" is a doll converted from his corpse and controlled by Ella, who is the "perfect doll" for Shaw, created just before her death. He screams as Ella, possessed by Mary Shaw, lunges at him. The film ends with Jamie reciting a nursery rhyme about Shaw and a photo album with human puppets is shown: Lisa, Henry, Detective Lipton, Edward, Ella, and Jamie himself. ==Cast== * [[Ryan Kwanten]] as Jamie Ashen * [[Amber Valletta]] as Ella Ashen * [[Donnie Wahlberg]] as Detective Jim Lipton * [[Bob Gunton]] as Edward Ashen * [[Judith Roberts (actress)|Judith Roberts]] as Mary Shaw * [[Michael Fairman]] as Henry Walker ** [[Keir Gilchrist]] as Young Henry * [[Laura Regan]] as Lisa Ashen * Joan Heney as Marion Walker * Shelley Peterson as Lisa's Mom * Steven Taylor as Michael Ashen * [[Dmitry Chepovetsky]] as Richard Walker * [[Enn Reitel]] as Billy (voice) * [[Fred Tatasciore]] as Clown Doll (voice) ==Release== ''Dead Silence'' was released in the United States on March 16, 2007,{{cite web|title=Release dates for Dead Silence (2007)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0455760/releaseinfo|work=IMDb|publisher=IMDb.com, Inc.|accessdate=1 August 2012|author=IMDb|year=1990–2012}} with an "[[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#Ratings|R]]" rating. ===Box office=== In the United States, as of April 16, 2007, the film's total domestic [[Gross (economics)|gross]] has been worth [[United States dollar|US$]]16.5 million (according to [[Box Office Mojo]]), and screenings of ''Dead Silence'' were ceased in most theatres sixteen days following its release; the film's estimated [[production budget]] was US$20 million. As of April 1, 2009, US$5,408,331 has been generated globally. Worldwide the film has grossed $22,217,407.{{cite web|title=Dead Silence|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=deadsilence.htm|work=Box Office Mojo|publisher=IMDb.com, Inc|accessdate=1 August 2012|author=Box Office Mojo}} Tentative plans for a [[sequel]] were abandoned.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} ===Critical reception=== {{expand section|date=November 2014}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has a rating of 21%, based on 77 reviews, with an average rating of 3.8/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "More tasteful than recent slasher flicks, but ''Dead Silence'' is undone by boring characters, bland dialogue, and an unnecessary and obvious [[twist ending]]."{{cite web|title=''Dead Silence'' (2007)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/dead_silence/|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=August 19, 2013}} On [[Metacritic]], the film holds a score of 34 out of 100, based on 15 reviews, indicating "generally unfavourable reviews".{{cite web|title=''Dead Silence'' (2007)|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/dead-silence|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CNET Networks]]|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} ===Home media=== The film was released on [[DVD]] on June 26, 2007 with an "[[Unrated films|unrated]]" version also released, and the same occurred for the [[HD DVD]] product. The film has since grossed US$17,304,718 in overall DVD sales.{{cite web|title=Dead Silence – DVD Sales|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2007/SLENC-DVD.php|work=The Numbers|publisher=Nash Information Services, LLC|accessdate=1 August 2012|author=The Numbers|year=1997–2012}} ''Dead Silence'' was released on [[Blu-ray Disc]] in the United Kingdom on October 25, 2010.{{cite web|title=''Dead Silence'' Blu-ray UK|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Dead-Silence-Blu-ray/15634/|website=Blu-ray.com|accessdate=27 May 2015}} In May 2015, it was announced that [[Universal Studios]] would be releasing the film to Blu-ray Disc in the U.S. It released on August 11, 2015.{{cite web|title=''Dead Silence'' Unrated Blu-ray|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=16804|website=Blu-ray.com|accessdate=27 May 2015}} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Dead Silence Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = Charlie Clouser, Aiden | cover = | alt = | released = March 16, 2007 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Score, [[horror punk]], [[gothic rock]] | length = 51:19 | label = [[Lakeshore Records]] | producer = Charlie Clouser, Aiden | prev_title = [[Saw III (soundtrack)|Saw III]] | prev_year = 2006 | next_title = [[Saw IV (soundtrack)|Saw IV]] | next_year = 2007 | misc = {{Singles | name = [[Rain in Hell]]'','' Dead Silence | type = soundtrack | single1 = [[We Sleep Forever]] | single1date = March 2007 }} }} [[Lakeshore Records]] released the soundtrack of ''Dead Silence'' on March 20, 2007. The CD contains 31 tracks, the first track being the song "[[We Sleep Forever]]" performed by American rock band [[Aiden]] (despite not actually being featured within the film itself). The rest of the CD is taken up by [[Charlie Clouser]]'s film's score. Clouser has worked on many film scores such as the ''[[Saw (franchise)|Saw]]'' series and ''[[Resident Evil: Extinction]]''. ;Track listing # "[[We Sleep Forever]]" – [[Aiden]] # "Main Titles" [2:56] # "Sheet" [1:08] # "Blood" [1:41] # "Apartment" [1:28] # "Raven's Fair" [0:59] # "Dad's House" [0:47] # "Ella" [1:29] # "My Son" [1:03] # "What Poem?" [1:31] # "Caskets" [1:57] # "Motel Hearse" [1:22] # "It Can't Be" [1:40] # "Funeral" [0:49] # "Billy" [2:42] # "Perplexed" [1:25] # "Steal Billy" [0:50] # "Lips Moving" [1:57] # "Coffin" [2:16] # "Photos" [1:36] # "Map Drive" [0:49] # "Guignol" [1:57] # "He Talked" [3:06] # "It's Soup" [2:09] # "Full Tank" [1:49] # "Doll Wall" [1:37] # "All the Dolls" [1:07] # "One Left" [0:27] # "Mary Shaw" [0:31] # "Dummy" [1:05] # "Family Album" [0:37] ==Alternate footage== Many alternate scenes were released on the unrated DVD and HD DVD and are listed below: * Detective Lipton has a conversation with his colleague before interrogating Jamie on Lisa's death. * Mary Shaw's performance at the theatre is extended. * Jamie walking through Mary Shaw's property is slightly extended. * The unrated version depicts Detective Lipton rowing the boat towards the dilapidated theatre to chase Jamie. * Mary Shaw is depicted several times throughout the unrated version with a long, slimy tongue, made of the numerous tongues from her victims. In the scenes, she uses her tongue to frighten her victims, making it slither from her mouth (and licks Jamie's cheek in one scene). Along with the tongues of her victims, Mary acquires their voices as well. * Jamie attempting to swim out of the theatre is slightly extended. * In an alternate ending, Ella simply knocks Jamie out after he discovers his father was a puppet all along. Then, she explains that the original Ella was a human being with Edward as an abusive husband. Edward knocked her down the stairs and killed their unborn child. Ella dug up the grave where the puppet Billy was buried and became possessed by Mary Shaw. Afterwards, Ella makes a family photograph, and then, dressed as Mary Shaw, tells a bedtime story to a child by candlelight, later revealed to be Jamie with his tongue ripped out (or would have been had they added the visual effect planned). This story is the poem. Ella also reveals that only silence can save you from Mary Shaw. Then she blows out the candle, ending the movie. * [[Billy the Puppet|The Billy puppet]], from the [[Saw (franchise)|''Saw'' franchise]], makes a brief [[Cameo appearance|cameo]]; it can be seen sitting on the floor as Jamie starts to walk towards the clown doll. ==Post-release commentary== In his personal [[blog]], screenwriter Whannell reveals the origins of the film within the context of the [[Film industry#Hollywood|"Hollywood" film industry]]. In a candid post entitled "Dud Silence: The Hellish Experience of Making a Bad Horror Film", Whannell explains that the film was conceived following the advice of his [[Talent agent|agent]] at the time and that a "[[script doctor]]" was eventually employed by the [[Film studio|production studio]]. Whannell concludes the post with a description of the key lessons that were learned following the ''Dead Silence'' experience:
After everything is said and done, I'm almost glad ''Dead Silence'' happened, because it gave me an extreme, coal-face lesson in what not to do. It was like learning to swim by leaping off Niagara Falls. I only write scripts on spec now, which means that I write them in my own time without getting paid and then take them out into the world to see if anyone's interested. Never again will I enter the arranged marriage of selling a pitch. I have also become very gun-shy about working with studios. In the world of independent film, what you write ends up on screen. Plus, they don't have the money to bring in script doctors! Works fine for me. Who knows, maybe one day I will work with a studio again...{{cite web|title=Dud Silence: The Hellish Experience Of Making A Bad Horror Film|url=http://thewordinthestone.com/#!111|work=Word In The Stone|publisher=Leigh Whannell|accessdate=1 August 2012|author=Leigh Whannell|date=31 August 2011}}
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://deadsilencemovie.net/}} * {{IMDb title|0455760|Dead Silence}} * {{mojo title|deadsilence|Dead Silence}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|dead_silence|Dead Silence}} * {{metacritic film|dead-silence|Dead Silence}} {{James Wan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dead Silence}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2007 horror films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American supernatural horror films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Charlie Clouser]] [[Category:Films directed by James Wan]] [[Category:Mannequins in films]] [[Category:Screenplays by James Wan]] [[Category:Ventriloquism]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Fiction about spirit possession]]

'''Euphorium''' was a [[Site-specific art|site-specific]] theater installation produced by [[Antenna Theater]] that ran from 2000 to 2002 in [[San Francisco, California]], [[London, England]], and [[Black Rock City, Nevada]].
The piece is based on [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]'s poem, [[Kubla Khan]]. It was one of a series of installations Antenna Theater's director, Chris Hardman, describes as "walkmanology", in which audience members are guided through a set wearing headphone devices. For Euphorium, the audience members were given specially-designed helmets that included not only stereo speakers, but also a periscope-like device by which they would view a diorama created on a room's ceiling as they walked slowly through the performance. Infrared triggers would initiate various [[mp3]]-encoded audio segments as they passed.<ref name=sfg/> The result was alternately described as an immersive [[multimedia]] performance,<ref>{{cite journal| publisher=Oxford University Press|title=Editing Environments: The Architecture of Electronic Texts|author=Neil Fraistat|url=http://llc.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/fqn032v1|date=2008}}</ref> and "[[Gothic aesthetics|gothic]] theater".<ref>{{cite book|page=215|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p4fnEHOuZ6UC&pg=PA214&dq=euphorium+coleridge|title=The Routledge Companion to Gothic|author=Catherine Spooner, Emma McEvoy|publisher=Routledge|date=2007|isbn=978-0-415-39843-5}}</ref>
Hardman had founded a successful company, [[Antenna Audio]], by applying the innovation to self-guided museum tours, beginning with [[Alcatraz Island]].<ref name=sfg>{{cite news|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|title=You're Dreaming: A psychedelic journey awaits all who find their way to Antenna Theater's "Euphorium'|author=Robert Hurwitt|date=2001-02-17|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/02/17/DD148057.DTL&hw=KUBLA&sn=003&sc=823}}</ref> The production also made use of a 19th-century optical technique known as "[[Pepper's Ghost]]", and various puppetry techniques, which Hardman learned in the 1970s as a member of [[Bread and Puppet Theater]] at [[Coney Island]].<ref name=sfg/><ref name=hm>{{cite news|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|title=Hardman does it with smoke, mirrors and a tape player|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/11/09/NB40913.DTL|author=Alex Horvath|date=2001-11-09}}</ref>
The initial production ran from 2000 to 2001 in an old army building in the [[Presidio of San Francisco]]<ref name=sfg/> that also included a mock [[opium den]].<ref name=hm/> In 2002-2003 Antenna partnered with Soho Theatre Company for a run in the cave-like basement of [[The Roundhouse]] in [[Camden Town]], London.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=British Broadcasting Company|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/london/entertainment/theatre/euphorium.shtml|title=The Euphor!um experience:From Xanadu to Camden |author=Mark Shenton}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/euphorium-the-stately-pleasuredome-camdenstyle-639683.html|title=Euphorium: The stately pleasure-dome, Camden-style; Coleridge's opium poetry fragment 'Kubla Khan' comes to life in a London undercroft|author=Phil Tinline|date=2002-08-11}}</ref>
==Reception== Critical response was mixed, with some complaining that the show's technology and effects were unrefined.<ref name=sfg/> The production was also criticized as being confusing, and showing a misunderstanding of the meaning of Coleridge's poem.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Curtain Up|date=2002|author=Brian Glover|url=http://www.curtainup.com/euphorium.html}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:2000 works]] [[Category:2000 establishments in California]] [[Category:2002 disestablishments in California]] [[Category:Art in San Francisco]] [[Category:Installation art works]] [[Category:Postmodern theatre]]
